HEADLINE: Stocks Slip on Worries Over Effects of Katrina

BYLINE: By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
The stock market gave up ground last week on concerns that the economy may be slowing and inflation rising in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. 
 Some investors will be in a holding pattern until Tuesday when Federal Reserve policy makers are to decide whether to raise short-term interest rates. 
The weekly market decline occurred despite a rally on Friday, which was not powerful enough to make up for earlier deficits.
 Consumer confidence fell sharply this month, according to a preliminary survey released on Friday by the University of Michigan. The drop in early September was bigger than the monthly decline after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, but some economists said it was likely to be temporary.
 For the week, Dow Jones industrial average declined by 36.62 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 10,641.94. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 3.57 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 1,237.91. The Nasdaq composite index fell 15.16 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 2,160.35. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 4.27 percent from 4.12 percent the previous week. Gold futures for December delivery rose to $464.50 an ounce. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: Don't Jump to Conclusions (Especially After Hurricanes)

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM. 
Paul J. Lim is a financial writer at U.S. News & World Report. E-mail: fund@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT'S easy to make snap judgments about events like Hurricane Katrina: bad news for the economy, at least in the short run, but good news for energy profits, right? It's also easy for investment strategies to be spun around by them. And that should be a consideration for any investor who's thinking of making major changes to a portfolio in Katrina's aftermath. 
 Days after Katrina crashed into the Gulf Coast -- disrupting vital ports and sending energy prices soaring in its immediate wake -- many investors quickly jumped to one of two conclusions.
For starters, a number of the stock market's bulls became convinced that the Federal Reserve would have to stop raising short-term interest rates, given the weakened state of the economy. Bears, meanwhile, thought that the storm could cause an inversion of the yield curve, meaning that yields on long-term bonds would begin to pay less than short-term securities. 
 Are either of these possibilities a lock? Let's start with the Fed. 
 Some people now think that when the Fed's monetary policy committee convenes on Tuesday, it will keep its target for the federal funds rate, which financial institutions charge one another on overnight loans, at 3.5 percent. Before Katrina, a quarter-point rate increase was considered a virtual certainty. If the Fed stops raising rates, conventional wisdom says the effects would be bullish for the equity markets. After all, stocks went on a tear after the Fed ended rate-tightening cycles in 1989 and 1995.
 Yet it's still far from certain that the Fed is done raising rates. In a speech in Chicago on Sept. 7, more than a week after Katrina dealt a body blow to the economy, Michael H. Moskow, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, expressed concern that core inflation was ''running at the upper end of the range that I feel is consistent with price stability.'' Such language would indicate that Fed officials are worried not only about post-Katrina economic growth, but also about the effects of higher energy and commodity prices on overall inflation. 
 Robert C. Doll, president and chief investment officer at Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, observes that ''there are now a bunch of people running around saying the Fed is done.'' In light of that new sentiment, he wonders, what will happen if the Fed announces another increase on Tuesday?
 And even if the Fed doesn't raise rates that day, it may not yet be finished. ''I could see the case for the Fed pausing in September or even November, based on the uncertainties generated by the storm,'' said Nicholas P. Sargen, chief investment officer at Fort Washington Investment Advisors. ''But if someone said to me that this is the end of the story on rate hikes, I would disagree with that.''
 Even if Mr. Sargen is wrong and the Fed is done for good, investors don't necessarily have a green light to start pumping money into equities. 
 Ned Davis Research studied the historical performance of the Dow Jones industrial average after Fed tightening cycles. While stocks did rally in a big way in 1989 and 1995, the average performance of the Dow in the 12 months after the Fed finishes has been a loss of 3.9 percent, dating back to 1920. In fact, in 9 of the last 16 cases, stocks have lost ground in the next 12 months. 
 What's important for investors isn't necessarily when the Fed is done tightening -- it's why. Is it stopping because inflation is no longer a threat or because the economy is slowing on its own? Or, worse, what if the Fed stops raising rates because the economy is in real trouble?
 Now, let's turn to the other snap judgment about Katrina: that it would prompt a flight to safety into bonds, theoretically driving down long-term interest rates to the point that they yield less than short-term debt. That phenomenon is called an inverted yield curve, and, historically, it has been an indicator of impending recession.
 The fear of an inverted curve seemed to be justified when worried investors drove money into Treasuries in the first four days after the storm, lowering the yield on the 10-year to as low as 3.98 percent from as high as 4.18 percent.
 Yet a little more than a week after the storm, the 10-year Treasury yield bounced back. On Friday, it stood at 4.27 percent.
 Indeed, market watchers are now divided about whether Katrina will invert the yield curve or do the opposite: steepen it. ''I can make arguments for both cases,'' said Tobias M. Levkovich, chief United States equity strategist at Citigroup. 
 For example, the bond market might rally -- and yields decline -- if investors truly feared that the economy would slow because of higher energy costs. Alternatively, bonds could just as easily sell off if investors started believing that those higher costs were leading to an inflationary spiral. That, in turn, could send long bond yields higher, steepening the curve.
 EVEN if the curve does invert, does that necessarily spell doom for the stock market? No. 
 To be sure, stocks do perform much better on average when the curve is flat or steep as opposed to inverted. But Mr. Levkovich recently studied stock market performance in periods after yield curve inversions, going back to 1920. In three of the last seven periods, the Standard & Poor's 500 index of blue-chip stocks actually gained ground in the year after the curve inverted.
 While inverted yield curves typically foreshadow recessions, which are bad for stocks, those recessions sometimes don't manifest themselves until one year -- or, in some cases, two -- after the inversion, said Anthony Chan, managing director and senior economist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management. So investors should try not to overreact.
 ''Today, information disperses so fast that we're reacting in nanoseconds to the news,'' Mr. Chan said. Yet, he said, our initial responses to market or economic turmoil often end up being wrong. 
 Mr. Chan's advice to investors: ''In these circumstances, you have to be careful not to react in the short-term to the noise, because the risk of being whipsawed is so great.''

HEADLINE: Out on Her Own, but Not for Long

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
HER business career and personal life have blended into one very sweet confection.
 In 2000, Dawn Casale left Barneys New York, where she had been the women's accessories manager at the Madison Avenue store, to become a cookie maker -- and cookie seller, packager, shipper and promoter. The one-person business she was starting was reflected in the name she chose for the venture, One Girl Cookies.
The baking was to be done in the small kitchen of her Greenwich Village apartment, and the other tasks wherever in the apartment they could be accommodated. 
 In her first full year, 2001, Ms. Casale sold 2,500 pounds of her petite handmade cookies, bringing in $34,000. Last year, by then with a co-owner (more about this later), the business sold 7,000 pounds for $150,000, Ms. Casale said recently. 
 She projects revenues this year of $300,000 from her cookies, which are still handmade, largely the size of a bite or two, and include varieties like a hazelnut sandwich filled with chocolate cinnamon ganache and a nut butter topped with toasted coconut. 
 By early 2002, Ms. Casale said, ''I realized I couldn't do it alone anymore.'' So she hired a baker (more about this, too, later) and moved into professional kitchen space in Manhattan that she sublet from a caterer, who became her first wholesale customer. Then, three weeks ago, One Girl moved into its latest home, at 68 Dean Street in Brooklyn, just off a trendy strip of Smith Street in Boerum Hill. It has a still larger production space as well as room for additions: a retail shop and a coffee bar, which will be completed soon. 
 The additions, Ms. Casale said, are among the changes that she hopes will spur a financial breakthrough, toward net returns greater than the annual ''small profits'' One Girl has realized so far. Revenues may have sharply increased, but as the business has grown, so have the costs.
 Why did she move to baking soda and butter from belts and brooches?
 After six years at Barneys, ''I felt I was at a dead end,'' said Ms. Casale, 34. A promotion to group manager, she said, would have involved ''a lot of time spent in the office'' rather than working on floor displays and dealing directly with salespeople, both of which she enjoyed.
 So she decided to build a business out of another activity that she had long enjoyed.
 Growing up, she said, she baked frequently with her mother and her three sisters. Also, the start-up costs of a home-based cookie business were minimal, she said, unlike the expansion expenses later. Those expenses, Ms. Casale said, have been partly financed with the aid of more than $100,000 in loans.
 Much of One Girl's early business came from, or through, customers, colleagues and vendors she had dealt with at Barneys. Word of mouth from satisfied customers helped, she said, as did promotional efforts like tastings at Dean & DeLuca, currently One Girl's largest wholesale customer. 
 Wholesale sales currently account for about 60 percent of One Girl's revenues, Ms. Casale said. Bernard Reynolds, executive vice president of the Retail Bakers of America, an industry group, said small bakeries whose revenues come largely from a small number of wholesale buyers ''may be more prone to pressure,'' if the buyers seek a lower price, than bakeries that rely more heavily on retail sales. 
 Ms. Casale agreed, saying that this was one reason for the planned retail shop, and for planned sales on an Internet site that is to be upgraded with a $2,000 small-business grant. The money was awarded by a program sponsored by the city's Department of Small Business Services and Commission on Women's Issues. One Girl's sales so far have largely been through telephone orders.
 The company now has two employees working with Ms. Casale and her co-owner. Which brings us to the information promised earlier. The co-owner and the baker she hired in 2002 are one and the same: David Crofton, who went from employee to business partner two years ago.
 Then, three months ago, they partnered again: they married.
 One need not ask where the cookies for that occasion came from.

HEADLINE: Gas Prices Shake Up Commuting Routines

BYLINE: By GREG CLARKIN

 BODY:
IN the predawn darkness, John Ficke picks up his coffee, then rounds up fellow commuters for the 60-mile drive from Torrington to Fairfield. 
 On the platform of the Bridgeport train station, Tony Davis can watch traffic crawl southbound on I-95, traffic he sat in a few weeks ago before switching to the train to New York.
On her hourlong drive from New Britain to Storrs, Janice Palmer has turned off the air-conditioning, sweating it out with the windows up while watching her speed.
 And Kristen Werden is ''pounding the pavement'' around her job in Shelton, working to find passengers for the van pool she is determined to start. 
 Different commuters with very different commutes, but driven to make a change by one common factor: $3-a-gallon gasoline.
 All across Connecticut, commuters are teaming up and slowing down, trading wheels for rails, all in an effort to save money on gas. Even as gas prices retreat from above $3.50 a gallon, many commuters have decided to make major changes to the way they travel to and from work to save money.
 ''Higher energy prices siphon off buying power,'' said Donald Klepper-Smith, chief economist with DataCore Partners, a consulting firm in New Haven. ''But people still need to get to work and still need to do the grocery shopping.'' 
 Mr. Klepper-Smith said it costs the average Connecticut family, with two cars to fuel and a house to heat, as much as $2,500 more a year than it did five years ago, a $200-a-month increase.
 The jump in gas prices over the last few months, capped by the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, forced many consumers to ''rethink their driving habits,'' he said.
 That's what it took for Mr. Ficke to alter his commute.
 ''When it got to the point where gas was costing me $30 a day, I had to do something,'' he said.
 He had always looked for car pool partners for his 120-mile-a-day commute, but a few weeks ago he went even further. He searched various ride-share Web sites, but was unable to find a match, so he began calling friends and acquaintances he could pick up and drop off along the way.
 As a result, some days he has as many as three passengers in his Dodge truck and makes multiple stops before arriving in Fairfield, where he is a transportation supervisor for the Board of Education.
 Mr. Davis abandoned his S.U.V. for the train to commute to his publishing job in New York when gas hit $3 a gallon.
 ''I probably save $200, maybe $250 a month,'' Mr. Davis said as he waited for a train in Bridgeport.
 Commuting by train also lets Mr. Davis leave for work later. It was after 7 a.m. as he waited for a train, a full hour later than when he used to leave when driving.
 Shemshat Soltanova, a paralegal in Norwalk, traded her car for the train from Bridgeport about six weeks after it became too costly to fill up her car.
 ''I don't want to use my car,'' she said. ''At these prices it would cost me $45 to fill it up for a week.'' Her monthly train ticket costs $58 and she estimates her monthly savings to be more than $200.
 But there are commuters who don't have the options of finding riders to share the costs or switching to mass transit.
 Ms. Palmer drives about 45 miles each way between New Britain and Storrs, where she is director of communications for the Neag School of Education at the University of Connecticut. She said that by late summer her gas bill was approaching $65 a week.
 ''It hurt when I figured it out,'' Ms. Palmer said.
 She set out to find passengers to car-pool with, but was unsuccessful. Her alternative was to change her driving habits. She asked herself ''What's in my power to do?
 ''I slowed down a bit on the highway and really stuck to the speed limit,'' she said. ''And I paid attention to not coming to quick stops and start-ups at stop signs.''
 And she closed the windows to reduce drag and shut off the air-conditioning.
 ''I shut it off on some of the hottest days of the year and it was quite a hot ride home,'' she said.
 All of the measures paid off.
 ''I honestly felt that I got one extra trip, one way, out of the five days,'' she said.
 The jump in gas prices have sparked a boom for organizations devoted to getting people out of their cars and into van pools. The offices of Rideshare in Windsor were swamped with calls over the Labor Day weekend. Connie Dice, vice president for business development, said that on a normal weekend Rideshare would get one or two e-mail messages or phone calls inquiring about its statewide commuter van service, Easy Street. The agency provides the van, and the riders share the driving and juggle the schedules, all for about $100 a person each month. Some of the vans go to New York City and other out-of-state destinations for Connecticut commuters. 
 ''Normally in a good quarter we're looking to start maybe seven vans,'' Ms. Dice said. ''We now have calls from 38 people interested in starting a service.''
 One of those new van pools could include Mrs. Werden. She commutes 40 miles round trip from Southbury to her job as a client services manager for Sirva Relocation in Shelton and is fed up with gas prices.
 ''As soon as it hit $2.75, $3 a gallon, it was just too much,'' Mrs. Werden said. Her gas bill was approaching $400 a month when she decided to act.
 ''I said, 'I just can't foresee spending this much money,''' she said.
 Mrs. Werden needs five other commuters to meet the minimum for a van, and she has lined up two co-workers so far. She is working with Easy Street and is posting fliers in the office building where she works to find the last three riders. 
 ''We can make it work,'' Mrs. Werden said.
 John Lyons, president of MetroPool, a transportation consulting firm in Stamford, has seen a surge in calls from commuters looking for other options.
 ''The intensity of the phone call is different,'' he said. ''It's much more urgent. People are saying, 'I can't deal with these prices anymore.'''
 Jean Stimolo, executive director of Rideworks Commuter Services in New Haven, has noticed that more and more companies are becoming involved in offering employees other ways to get to work.
 ''Some companies are being motivated by $3-a-gallon gas prices,'' Ms. Stimolo said. ''We've had a number of companies come to us,'' looking for van pools for their employees. 
 And statistics show Metro-North benefiting from the high gas prices. Dan Brucker, a spokesman, said a count of riders into Grand Central Terminal during the morning rush hour on Sept. 8 found an increase of 3 to 4 percent, more than double what Metro-North expected. There were an additional 2,500 riders spread evenly across the railroad's three lines.
 Mr. Brucker called the increase ''uncommon'' and said that it ''represents a significant jump in the number of customers.''

 Metro-North stations like the one in Fairfield, above, are much busier because of higher gas prices. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sikorsky's Airship Enterprise (Of Sorts)

BYLINE: By JEFF HOLTZ

 BODY:
STRATFORD has long been known for building helicopters, but lately it has become a popular port of call for airships.
 In the last couple of years, an increasing amount of airships, otherwise known as blimps, decorated with advertisements have been using Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford as a temporary base between flying over major sports events, concerts and beaches in the New York metropolitan area.
Kurt Sendlein, operations manager at Sikorsky, said the number of airports that have a large open fields that can accommodate the blimps is dwindling. 
 ''There are just fewer places for them now,'' he said.
 The Ameriquest Airship Freedom is 207 feet long, 60 feet tall and filled with 270,000 cubic meters of helium. It travels about 50 miles an hour at about 1,500 feet, though the craft can go as high as 9,000 feet.
 George Spyrou is president of Airship Management Services in Greenwich, which owns six airships worldwide, including the $5.5 million Ameriquest tethered at Sikorsky last week.
 Mr. Spyrou said that since the 2001 terrorist attacks, security concerns at airports closer to New York City have made landing spots more scarce. 
 ''We've have encountered more and more restrictions,'' he said. ''Sikorsky has become attractive to us because we're still in the region, but we can skirt the controlled airspace in New York most of the time.'' 
 Mr. Spyrou also said his airships have been used by the New York City police department for surveillance. 
 Mr. Sendlein said that airships visit Sikorsky Airport about 20 times a year and that the fees they generate amount to about $20,000 yearly. He said their presence also helps the area's economy. 
 ''Some have crews of close to 20 people that travel with them in trucks and vans and use local hotels restaurants and other businesses, and visit attractions in the area when they are not working,'' Mr. Sendlein said. 
 David Anderson, a member of the ground crew for the Hood airship, which left Sikorsky last Monday for a three-hour flight to Boston, said the topography near the airport also makes it ideal. 
 ''There aren't a lot of hills and trees that can create unstable air that can move the ship around a lot,'' he said.
 When a blimp is tethered at Sikorsky, one crew member is constantly on site, watching the ship and checking helium levels. 
 The blimps frequently cover 250 to 300 miles a day. The Ameriquest blimp holds eight passengers, and a pilot and co-pilot. 
 Katherine Board, 30, one of the pilots of the Hood ship, which holds four passengers and one pilot, also said Sikorsky is a good stopping point.
 ''There is a heavy population around here, so whoever is advertising on the ship gets great exposure,'' she said. ''And the people who run the airport are very good. They look out for us.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: The Ameriquest Airship Freedom, 207 feet long and 60 feet tall, was recently tethered in an open field at Sikorsky Memorial Airport, left. Below, a worker inspecting the craft. (Photographs by Douglas Healey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Conventional Wisdom

BYLINE: By Akhil Reed Amar. 
Akhil Reed Amar, professor of law at Yale, is the author of ''America's Constitution: A Biography.''

 BODY:
EVERY year, Sept. 17 to Sept. 23 is officially designated Constitution Week, celebrating the fact that during this stretch in 1787, the Philadelphia framers unveiled their handiwork. But the only thing that happened then and there was that a proposed Constitution signed by several dozen statesmen became public. 
 Only months later did the document actually become law, after Americans agreed to it in a series of unprecedented votes held from Georgia to New Hampshire. In that unsung ratification process, New York emerged as the decisive battleground state -- the Florida and Ohio of the 1780's. 
When the Philadelphia framers floated their proposal, they knew the difficulty of the task that lay ahead. Never in history had so many people been allowed to vote on the basic ground rules of government. Even the most democratic of ancient Greek constitutions had been handed down from on high by individuals -- Athens's Solon and Sparta's Lycurgus -- rather than voted on by the citizenry. In America, ordinary citizens had not been invited to ratify the Declaration of Independence or the various state constitutions written in 1776 or the continental Articles of Confederation drafted in 1777. 
 In dramatic contrast, the 1787 Philadelphia proposal by its own terms would not go into effect unless at least nine out of 13 state conventions said yes. Significant too, was the state-by-state adoption of special election rules enabling ratification conventions to represent the people in an especially democratic manner. New York led the way, temporarily waiving its usual requirement that voters had to own a certain amount of property and, for the first time in its history, allowing all free male adult citizens to select convention delegates. 
 New York also let all freemen serve as convention delegates, regardless of whether they met the usual property requirements for serving in the State Senate. Of course by modern standards, even this voting base, which excluded slaves and women, was too narrow. Yet it was far broader than anything previously seen in New York -- or in most other places, for that matter -- and thus set a precedent for further voting expansions in later years. 
 New York also led the way in deciding the Constitution's fate and clarifying its central meaning. In mid-June 1788, a full nine months after its conception at Philadelphia, the Constitution was still struggling to be born. Eight states had said yes, one shy of the mark. Then, New Hampshire and Virginia voted their approval -- enough to put the document in operation, but only among the states that ratified it. At this point, all eyes turned to Poughkeepsie, where New York's ratifying convention was being held and where the Constitution's anti-Federalist opponents initially held a commanding lead. Without the acquiescence of New York -- with its critical harbors, rivers and landmass -- could the Philadelphia blueprint really work as planned? 
 In late July, the Poughkeepsie convention finally said yes, by a vote of 30 to 27. A switch of only two votes would have reversed the outcome. 
 With New York now safely on board, the document's future was assured. True, Rhode Island and North Carolina had yet to say yes, but neither state was militarily nor economically indispensable. Thus the Constitution's more perfect union initially went into effect without the two stragglers; when George Washington took his oath of office in early 1789, he did so as president of the 11 United States.
 But exactly how were these states united? Did a state that said yes in the 1780's retain the right to unilaterally say no later on, and thereby secede? If not, why not?
 Once again, it was in New York that the answer emerged most emphatically. At the outset of the Poughkeepsie convention, anti-Federalists held a strong majority. The tide turned when word arrived that New Hampshire and Virginia had said yes to the Constitution, at which point anti-Federalists proposed a compromise: they would vote to ratify, but if the new federal government failed to embrace various reforms that they favored, ''there should be reserved to the state of New York a right to withdraw herself from the union after a certain number of years.''
 At the risk of alienating swing voters and losing on the ultimate ratification vote, Federalists emphatically opposed the compromise. In doing so, they made clear to everyone -- in New York and in the 12 other states where people were following the New York contest with interest -- that the Constitution did not permit unilateral state secession. Alexander Hamilton read aloud a letter at the Poughkeepsie convention that he had received from James Madison stating that ''the Constitution requires an adoption in toto, and for ever.'' Hamilton and John Jay then added their own words, which the New York press promptly reprinted: ''a reservation of a right to withdraw'' was ''inconsistent with the Constitution, and was no ratification.'' 
 Thus, it was New York where the document became an irresistible reality and where its central meaning -- one nation, democratic and indivisible -- emerged with crystal clarity. Move over, Philadelphia. New York, too, deserves credit this week as Americans commemorate our Constitution.

HEADLINE: Looking For a House And a Turret

BYLINE: By JOYCE COHEN. 
E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com

 BODY:
A VICTORIAN mansion -- that's the kind of home Cynthia von Buhler was holding out for. Was it possible?
 It was certainly worth a try. Ms. von Buhler would stay up late, scrutinizing online listings for grand historic homes, and searching the Craigslist Web site for words like ''mansion.''
 ''Believe it or not, there are some,'' she said.
 A Victorian mansion suits her. She and her former husband owned one in Boston, where they lived with many pets -- cats, birds and even rats -- that she uses as models for her artwork. Ms. von Buhler, an illustrator and multimedia artist, is of some renown in Boston, where a larger-than-life photograph of her was posted for several months earlier this year on a highway billboard advertising the Calendar section of The Boston Globe. 
 Nearly four years ago, in the midst of a divorce, she moved to Manhattan's meatpacking district. She was living in a gigantic loft that was also used as a gallery and event space when she went online and met Russell Farhang, a jazz violinist with a day job in technology management.
 Eventually, they spent most of their time at his place, a big one-bedroom rental in Park Slope, Brooklyn. It wasn't in great shape, but it was only $950 a month and, unlike the loft, didn't have strangers constantly traipsing through.
 But Ms. von Buhler, 40, dreamed of a bigger place, where she could fit all of her artwork and animals, and where they could settle long term. Mr. Farhang, 31, was starting to feel that buying was financially prudent.
 ''I am risk-averse and cautious, whereas Cynthia is completely impulsive, so we offset each other well,'' he said. ''She was saying, 'Let's go get something now.' I was saying, 'I would like to wait a year.' I was afraid of what it would mean to go from paying $950 a month to $4,000 all of a sudden.''
 Both got their way. They started hunting, but it took a year to find a place that made them truly happy.
 They initially thought of buying a two-bedroom apartment in a Brooklyn brownstone, but Mr. Farhang decided they were several years too late. ''Brooklyn is over from a buying perspective,'' he said. ''It seemed sad to buy a place for $400,000 to $500,000 that was smaller than the one we were renting for $950.'' 
 They pored over brownstoner.com, a favorite Web site, which decried inflation in Brooklyn and confirmed their own observations on price.
 ''I would get discouraged and say, 'Let's forget it and in the meantime we will save every penny,''' Mr. Farhang said. ''But Cynthia would take the computer into the other room and house hunt for hours, and in the morning there would be all these e-mails waiting for me.'' 
 Another favorite Web site, forgotten-ny.com, introduced them to places they had never heard of. Often, on weekends, the two would pick a neighborhood that sounded interesting and drive out, just to see. Ms. von Buhler swooned over the Victorian mansions in Ditmas Park. They identified the houses they liked by color -- pink, blue, green.
 But all were overpriced or in grave disrepair. The pink house, at more than $900,000, was appraised for much less. The blue house, at almost $1 million, was far from the subway. The green house, at around $800,000, was not just run-down but had ''what appeared to be drug-addicted squatters living there intermittently,'' Mr. Farhang said.
 By the new year, they started reading about the encroachment of Manhattan megabrokers into Ditmas Park, and noticed that prices were soaring.
 ''When we started looking, nobody was selling,'' Ms. von Buhler said. ''We weren't seeing the really gorgeous houses but the smaller versions that were not architecturally unique.'' Now, houses that seemed overpriced at $850,000 were listed for more than $1 million.
 By now, though, even Mr. Farhang was sold on the idea of a mansion. ''We realized it might be worth it to get something really big and extraordinary'' and move yet farther out, he said. They hoped to spend $700,000 to $800,000, or $1 million at the very most.
 Farther out included Jersey City, where they fell for a Victorian mansion, all Gothic splendor, on Reservoir Avenue. In the filthy basement, they found three ill feral kittens. ''We couldn't leave them there to die, so we gathered them up, with great difficulty,'' Mr. Farhang said. In the clutter, they even found a cat carrier. They stuffed the kittens inside and took them home.
 Later, the owner said the house was on a double lot, so he was selling it without the driveway and garage. He would be erecting a small building on the lot next door, blocking the view of Manhattan.
 ''I loved that house,'' Ms. von Buhler said. ''It needed a lot of work but I was willing to do that. I like saving houses just like I like saving cats.'' They haggled over the $800,000 price, but the owner wouldn't budge. ''It was heartbreaking,'' she said. ''Russell had more resilience. He could see something and separate himself from it. He was the voice of reason, which was really necessary.''
 When they found a two-family Victorian in Jersey City, they quickly offered the $800,000 asking price. ''We didn't want to lose it, so infected were we by real-estate-panic hysteria,'' Mr. Farhang said. And they liked the agent, who was sweet and soft-spoken and said she lived down the street.
 But they didn't like her enough to want her living in their house. Only when they read the contract did they see that the agent lived in the ground-floor apartment -- and, as a condition of the sale, would live there indefinitely for a rent of $700. The current owner, an elderly woman, would also be allowed to stay.
 ''Why would we buy the house if there were still going to be people in it?'' Mr. Farhang said. ''We made it clear we wanted to live there. The whole thing was sour. I became more and more hateful and angry at the whole process. We realized there was a seamy underside during this kind of market.'' 
 And then, one day, they noticed Staten Island. ''It was like we opened up a present we had forgotten about,'' Mr. Farhang said. So off they went. 
 They saw a few houses with Tina Sirico, an agent at Sari Kingsley Real Estate in New Dorp. The houses in Staten Island seemed beautiful and well-kept, and much cheaper than houses elsewhere. They were surprised and thrilled, especially when they visited a four-story, 2,500-square-foot Mediterranean-style villa, with a curved staircase inside and a lush garden outside. It looked like a castle. The house, in the St. George section, was listed at $659,000. 
 Trying to contain their excitement, they waited until that evening to place their bid. They bought the house for $655,000.
 According to the sellers, Laura Drew Kelly and Michael Kelly, who moved to Dover, Del., the house was built around 1929 by a Spanish teacher from Spain, who wanted a home reminiscent of his country.
 Ms. von Buhler and Mr. Farhang moved in last month, ceding the Park Slope place to Ms. von Buhler's youngest sister, Christina Carrozza, and her new husband, Brian D'Alessandro. 
 In Staten Island, they have found an ideal combination of house, location and price, said Mr. Farhang, who commutes by ferry. The house isn't a Victorian, like every other house Ms. von Buhler loved, but it had a turret. The octagonal room inside is for guests. They hope to persuade more of their friends to visit.
 To that end, the two are creating a Staten Island Web site, prodigalborough.com. ''Because of the real estate crunch, Staten Island is being welcomed back to the fold and being recognized as an underrated and extraordinary place to live,'' Mr. Farhang said. ''Everyplace else has a cool Web presence, but there is no hipster stuff for Staten Island -- just Yellow Page listings.''

HEADLINE: Downtown Hartford's New Centerpiece 

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: Hartford 

 BODY:
IN 1997, a group of Hartford insurance and utility executives proposed an ambitious -- some would say quixotic -- 33-acre mixed-use project for Hartford, then mired in a long and deep recession. It was to be named Adriaen's Landing, for an obscure Dutch explorer, Adriaen Block, who sailed up the Connecticut River and disembarked at the site in 1611.
 The idea was picked up a year later by Gov. John G. Rowland and the Legislature, which committed up to $1 billion for property acquisition, remediation and construction of a 540,000-square-foot convention center and 2,556-car parking structure to be owned by the state, as well as infrastructure improvements like utilities and landscaping. 
Today, the project has used about $850 million of the $1 billion, and two major components have had their grand openings in recent months. 
 On Aug. 25, the 22-story Marriott Hotel drew the usual array of state and local officials to its opening ceremonies. Earlier, on June 5, the adjoining Connecticut Convention Center opened.
 Now the hotel, convention center and landscaping that amounts to a public park have become the centerpiece of a new business and tourist destination on Columbus Boulevard, just off Exit 29A of Interstate 91, overlooking the Connecticut River. 
 The $150 million 409-room limestone hotel has a traditional appearance on the outside, but its interior is boldly colorful and appointed with vibrant wall finishes and patterned carpets. The circular lobby has cadmium yellow walls sprinkled with fanciful white stars, and the floor is a marble mosaic. Vivo, a spacious 180-seat Tuscan restaurant, has a semi-open kitchen and a color scheme of deep reds and dark brown woods; a royal blue and cream-colored bar called Crush can seat 110 at the bar and in semicircular banquettes; and next to the lobby is a Starbucks cybercafe and lounge with a plasma television and a fireplace. 
 A pool, a whirlpool tub accommodating up to eight people and a fitness center featuring Precor equipment occupy the 22nd floor, and eight suites ranging from $400 to $850 a night are on Floors 20 and 21. Rates for the regular rooms, on Floors 2 through 19, start at around $189.
 The hotel is designed to accommodate an addition -- if built, it would bring the number of rooms to 700 -- and the convention center can also be enlarged by another 200,000 square feet. Consumer demand has so far exceeded expectations, but decisions on expanding would depend on further evidence that the additional space is actually needed.
 Initial hotel occupancy is at 50 percent and rising. Bookings for 38,000 nights have been confirmed through 2006. The hotel has 21,800 square feet of banquet, meeting and ballroom space.
 Confirmed bookings at the convention center extend into 2010, with more than 250 events through June of 2006. ''Our first contract was signed in 2002,'' said Ben Seidel, the general manager, ''responding to ads in trade magazines around the country.'' Among other things, the advertisements noted that the center is within a 30-minute drive of 30 golf courses. 
 Reservations for both buildings are coming from organizations that in the past have had meetings in Providence, Charlotte, Pittsburgh and Philadelphia and that never gave Hartford a glance until now.
 Ed Dombroskas, tourism director at the Connecticut Commission of Culture and Tourism, said a big selling point ''is the unique combination of hotel and convention center'' in close proximity. ''Conventions by their very nature are always looking for adjacent hotels,'' he said. 
 Still to be built are the five-story 140,000-square-foot Connecticut Center for Science and Exploration, designed by Cesar Pelli, which is set to break ground on Oct. 21. This facility will have a museum aimed mainly at students in Grades 4 to 12, and its programs will tie in with the science curriculum in Hartford schools. 
 Later, some 200 condominium units and 100,000 square feet of stores, restaurants and entertainment venues covering six and a half acres are to be developed privately by the H.B. Nitkin Group of Greenwich. Robert A.M. Stern will be the master planner of Nitkin's projects, which are to occupy the west side of the Adriaen's Landing site. 
 The overall master planner and builder for Adriaen's Landing is Len Wolman, a sandy-haired 50-year-old developer who immigrated in 1976 and still speaks with a soft South African accent. He is chairman of the Waterford Group and its five subsidiaries, based in Waterford, Conn. 
 He and his brother Mark, 47, who is president, took over the existing Waterford Company, which had a single hotel, in 1986. Since then, they have built a $2 billion portfolio of 29 hotels in 10 states, in alliances with the Marriott, Holiday Inn, Radisson and Sheraton hotel chains. 
 They also build and manage convention properties and gaming resorts, including the Mohegan Sun in Uncasville, Conn. The brothers cut their developers' teeth transforming their parents' farm outside Johannesburg into a modest housing enclave with a convenience store. 
 Len Wolman recalled that in 1998 ''the governor called us and asked us to get involved in Adriaen's Landing; we had had contact with him on the Mohegan Sun project.'' The state's commitment to spend enormous sums persuaded him to get involved, especially as ''there is the resurgence around the country'' of developments in downtown locations.
 He retains ownership of the hotel, to which his company contributed $31.5 million, and Waterford will manage the entire complex. 
 The city stands to benefit from the new developments through so-called tax fixing, said Lee Erdman, the city manager. This requires payments in lieu of taxes by the convention center, which because of its state ownership would normally be exempt from property taxes. Calculated at 38 percent of the going rate for a for-profit property of this size, it will pay $1.9 million in 2005 and $2.3 million in 2006. The Marriott will pay $240,779 this year and $185,000 next year, when a long-term formula takes effect that is based on 1 percent of estimated annual gross revenues. 
 These are not insignificant amounts in Hartford, which is burdened with a collection of tax-exempt colleges, hospitals and state and municipal offices. Such tax-exempt properties have an estimated value in excess of $1.9 billion, out of total properties citywide of $3 billion. Referring to decades of decline in the value of most commercial, business and personal property, Mr. Erdman said, ''We have turned the corner, but it's going to be a long road.'' 
 At the far end of the area to be developed by the Nitkin Group, the Hartford Times building has been demolished, except for its imposing stone facade.
 The Wadsworth Atheneum, America's oldest art museum, which is across Prospect Street, will build a 54,000-square-foot annex that incorporates the facade. It will hold some of the museum's administrative offices and storage, meeting and educational space, food service and great art on the walls, but no galleries.


GRAPHIC: Photo: PART OF A $1 BILLION PLAN -- Len Wolman, master planner for Adriaen's Landing, in front of the 22-story Marriott hotel and the 540,000-square-foot convention center. (Photo by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

Editors' Choice
Other recent books of particular interest
THE PAINTED DRUM, by Louise Erdrich. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) A ceremonial drum is magically linked to children and death in Erdrich's latest novel set among the Ojibwa.
 JERRY ENGELS, by Thomas Rogers. (Handsel, $23.) Whatever happens to the namesake of this novel, he feels good about it. A dangerous trait.
 FIVE FAMILIES: The Rise, Decline, and Resurgence of America's Most Powerful Mafia Empires, by Selwyn Raab. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $29.95.) A colorful history of thuggery. 
 THEATRE OF FISH: Travels Through Newfoundland and Labrador, by John Gimlette. (Knopf, $25.) A journey through the barren lands whose chief resource, fish, has departed. 
 TOOTH AND CLAW, by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Viking, $25.95.) In this story collection, Boyle exposes silly folk to forces that gobble them up. 
 LITTLE CHAPEL ON THE RIVER: A Pub, a Town and the Search for What Matters Most, by Gwendolyn Bounds. (Morrow, $23.95.) Author finds peace in Irish bar 50 miles up the Hudson.
 THE TENDER BAR: A Memoir, by J. R. Moehringer. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Author finds adoptive family in Long Island bar (now defunct). 
 HENRY ADAMS AND THE MAKING OF AMERICA, by Garry Wills. (Houghton Mifflin, $30.) Arguing that Adams's histories have been poorly understood, Wills sees him as a champion of Jefferson and democracy. 
 PORNIFIED: How Pornography Is Transforming Our Lives, Our Relationships, and Our Families, by Pamela Paul. (Times Books/Holt, $25.) Paul finds that increased supply has raised demand and that Internet porn is often violent.
 MADE IN DETROIT: A South of 8-Mile Memoir, by Paul Clemens. (Doubleday, $23.95.) Clemens (born in 1973) recalls growing up working-class white in a black city losing both people and jobs.
 THE KNIFE MAN: The Extraordinary Life and Times of John Hunter, Father of Modern Surgery, by Wendy Moore. (Broadway, $26.) A scientist ahead of his time, except in his ethics.
 The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

BYLINE: By Ihsan Taylor

 BODY:
UP FROM ZERO: Politics, Architecture, and the Rebuilding of New York, by Paul Goldberger. (Random House, $14.95.) ''Up From Zero'' is a vivid tale of the long, complex and still unfinished struggle over what should go up in the place of the World Trade Center. Goldberger, a Pulitzer Prize-winning architecture critic, recounts the trade center's emergence in Lower Manhattan; describes three years of proposals and counterproposals for rebuilding the 16-acre site; and introduces the full cast of politicians, developers, architects and city planners competing to shape ''the most challenging urban-design problem of the 21st century.''

A COMPLICATED KINDNESS, by Miriam Toews. (Counterpoint, $13.95.) Toews's third novel is a misfit's coming-of-age story that takes place in the 1970's and 80's in a claustrophobic Mennonite community in rural Manitoba. In a series of flashbacks, her cocky, brooding 16-year-old narrator, Nomi, revisits moments in the breakdown of her relationship with her family and of her family's relationship with the citizens of their town.

HARD LINE: Life and Death on the U.S.-Mexico Border, by Ken Ellingwood. (Vintage, $14.) Ellingwood, a Los Angeles Times correspondent, follows the dangerous traffic of drugs and illegal immigrants across the 1,952-mile border, and examines the impact of Operation Gatekeeper -- America's effort to seal off sections of the border -- on migrant workers, ranchers and Border Patrol agents.

HAD A GOOD TIME: Stories From American Postcards, by Robert Olen Butler. (Grove, $13.) Drawing from the images and scrawled messages in his collection of early-20th-century picture postcards, Butler conjures 15 short stories that portray, and often parody, Americana.

JEROME ROBBINS: His Life, His Theater, His Dance, by Deborah Jowitt. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Born Jerome Wilson Rabinowitz, Robbins (1918-98) emerged as a Broadway dancer in 1943-44, and went on to choreograph and often direct an amazing series of shows: ''Peter Pan'' (1954), ''Bells Are Ringing'' (1956), ''West Side Story'' (1957), ''Gypsy'' (1959), ''Funny Girl'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof'' (both 1964). Jowitt, a dance critic at The Village Voice, chronicles Robbins's career, touching on his bisexuality, ambivalence about his Jewish heritage and appearance before the House Un-American Activities Committee in the 1950's.

THE LONG MEADOW: Poems, by Vijay Seshadri. (Graywolf, $14.) Seshadri's engaging second collection ranges from Russian Church history to the Three Little Pigs and includes a prose memoir of several pages, in which the author uses his father's obsession with the Civil War to explore the immigrant experience.

RUNNING ON EMPTY: How the Democratic and Republican Parties Are Bankrupting Our Future and What Americans Can Do About It, by Peter G. Peterson. (Picador, $15.) A successful investment banker and former secretary of commerce, Peterson blames all sides for our bleak fiscal future, brought on, he argues, by undertaxing, overspending and recklessly promising government benefits that cannot be financed.

JONATHAN STRANGE & MR. NORRELL, by Susanna Clarke. (Bloomsbury, $15.95.) Clarke's lively literary fantasy involves a Yorkshire magician named Gilbert Norrell who arrives in London in 1806 to rehabilitate English magic. Enter Jonathan Strange -- young, handsome and impetuous -- who arranges to study with Mr. Norrell. Gradually Strange sets himself up as Norrell's rival and threatens to topple all that his mentor has achieved. ''Clarke's imagination is prodigious, her pacing is masterly and she knows how to employ dry humor in the service of majesty,'' Gregory Maguire wrote in the Book Review.

TALES TO ASTONISH: Jack Kirby, Stan Lee, and the American Comic Book Revolution, by Ronin Ro. (Bloomsbury, $14.95.) Ro's book is a crisp primer on the origins of the comic-book industry and the partnership that in the 1960's established the superhero genre's template, creating the Hulk, the Fantastic Four and the X-Men.

HERE KITTY KITTY, by Libaire Jardine. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) There are glittering descriptions of New York life in this dark and tender first novel, in which a Tribeca restaurant manager finally bottoms out on drugs and drink, and begins a long struggle to take care of herself. Ihsan Taylor

HEADLINE: Corporate Makeover

BYLINE: By ALEXANDRA JACOBS. 
Alexandra Jacobs is an editor at The New York Observer.

 BODY:
BAIT AND SWITCH
 The (Futile) Pursuit of the American Dream.
 By Barbara Ehrenreich.
 237 pp. Metropolitan Books/
 Henry Holt & Company. $24.
The esteemed journalist Barbara Ehrenreich has made her name as a stalwart critic of capitalism, yet her new book, the latest of a baker's dozen on her resume, embodies one of that economic system's central tenets. It's a spinoff, a sequel, an attempted variation on a successful theme. 
 That previous success was an outraged treatise called ''Nickel and Dimed,'' wherein Ehrenreich -- whose background and education (a B.A. from Reed College and a Ph.D. from Rockefeller University) situate her firmly in the upper-middle class -- related how she hid her identity and took a succession of low-paying jobs to examine firsthand how the other half survives in America. Shakily, very shakily, was her predictable but nonetheless worthy conclusion. Though it drew ire from some real-life wage slaves, ''Nickel and Dimed'' was generally heaped with critical praise (Studs Terkel, for one, welcomed it with a ''Bravo!''). Published early in the somber year of 2001, the book spent nearly two years on the best-seller list, and still makes the occasional appearance there.
 This time, Ehrenreich decided to perform a similar undercover experiment on a different, and slightly less remote, tax bracket: American white-collar workers, corporate functionaries -- the kind of people she'd hitherto glimpsed only on airplanes, where, she notes with characteristic dryness, ''they study books on 'leadership,' fiddle with spreadsheets on their laptops, or fall asleep over biographies of the founding fathers.'' Think midlevel managers like the pointy-haired boss in Scott Adams's comic strip ''Dilbert,'' or Steve Carell's Michael Scott in the stateside remake of the BBC television program ''The Office'' -- pieces of pop culture with which Ehrenreich, who bemoans the loss of literary paper-pusher archetypes like 1955's ''Man in the Gray Flannel Suit,'' seems unacquainted. These are people trapped in a sort of power sandwich between the hapless, low-paid, entry-level drones under their immediate supervision, and the faceless, remote, overcompensated chief executives they aim to please; they are people who believe in the system, even though they're not necessarily rewarded by it. 
 Indeed, as Ehrenreich indicates, a growing number of the American unemployed are white-collar professionals who have been downsized, to use the still-popular parlance of the recessionary 1990's. A woman who can readily summon the works of Robert Lowell and Thomas Pynchon to underscore a point, she is aghast at this kind of business jargon, a positive blizzard of which she encounters during the course of her project -- words and phrases like ''takeaway,'' ''skill set,'' ''due diligence'' and ''in real time.'' It appears, though, that a bit of it did seep into her subconscious (''I would do everything possible to land a job,'' she writes in her introduction, ''utilizing whatever books, Web sites, and businesses that I could find offering guidance to job seekers''). Utilizing -- arrrgh! 
 As during the research for ''Nickel and Dimed,'' when she cushioned her situation with an ever-ready car and an emergency A.T.M. card, Ehrenreich goes only semi-gonzo in ''Bait and Switch.'' She chooses to pursue a position in public relations -- ''journalism's evil twin'' -- reasoning that it will require much the same ''skill set'' that a published writer has. But finding a job proves more difficult than it was in the previous book, where she was filling out an application form one minute and donning a Wal-Mart smock the next. Unfortunately, this prolonged search, conducted partly in a snappy new beige Ann Taylor pantsuit, also makes for a less dramatic narrative than that of a renowned essayist scrubbing toilets. This time around, Ehrenreich gets a Social Security card in her maiden name, Alexander; submits to the ministrations of a perky career coach named Kimberly; repeatedly revises her resume; and gets a Color Me Beautiful-style image consultation. ''What I had not understood is that to become an object, a thing, you must first go through a kind of death,'' she remarks, gazing at her painted self in the mirror -- shades of Simone de Beauvoir. Her fear of being exposed as a fraud in this world proves unfounded; for, it turns out, all of its denizens wear some form of protective camouflage.
 Much of ''Bait and Switch'' amounts to nothing more than annotated minutes of group networking sessions and job fairs, the kind that tend to take place in dismal, anodyne hotel conference chambers, with posturing attendees wearing plastic nametags and scrabbling for stale danishes along with gainful employment. Unsurprisingly, these events prove excruciating for Ehrenreich -- and by extension, the reader. ''It occurs to me that much of my job search so far has involved sitting in windowless rooms while someone -- most commonly a white male in his 50's or 60's -- stands at the front testifying, preaching, exhorting or coaching,'' she notes. The lectures, the jargon-clogged meetings, the fruitless hours spent at home working the phone and Googling at a computer -- these supposedly novel settings are not quite distinct enough from the author's normal turf to offer conviction that she is embarking on a true reporting adventure. Shifting restlessly in her seat, Ehrenreich seems to have contracted a case of metaphysical hemorrhoids: ''While blue-collar workers invite injury and exhaustion through physical exertion, white-collar workers endure the sometimes equally painful results of immobility,'' she sighs. ''At the moment, I'd rather be waitressing.''
 After months of these dull ''data drops,'' during which she discovers the shortcomings of her curriculum vitae (having an unexplained ''gap'' is a serious infraction, as is working at the Gap), Ehrenreich finally gets a couple of freelance, non-P.R. job offers: from Aflac, the insurance company known for its quacking duck spokesmodel, and Mary Kay, the cosmetics concern that famously offers its best saleswomen pink Cadillacs. What wouldn't one give to see Barbara Ehrenreich sailing down the highway in a pink Cadillac? But she swats them away, preferring to focus on the hypocrisies of the career coaches and image consultants, a cottage industry that has sprung up to train white-collar workers ''in transition'' -- a cottage industry, in fairness, mostly composed of white-collar workers ''in transition'' themselves. These, apparently, are the true bait-and-switchers of the title, selling vocational succor but offering gibberish and pablum.
 The problem is that the author, so comfortable as a champion of the disenfranchised, evinces such palpable disdain for this flawed but enterprising milieu. ''The dislike is reaching hatelike dimensions,'' she writes of poor Kimberly, the career coach. ''She represents something about the corporate world that repels me, some deep coldness masked as relentless cheerfulness.'' Toward Patrick, who runs a sad-sack motivational boot camp, she can muster nothing but ''pity . . . contempt for his entire profession.'' A Christian career ministry, which surely gives some poor souls solace, is dismissed as ''a realm drained of all transcendence and beauty.'' And her striving seminar tablemates are simply pronounced ''Fools!'' The book's balance sheet winds up tilting more sardonic than sympathetic -- and at the end of the day, as it were, it is we who feel vaguely swindled. Alas, as with New Coke, this derivative of a proven formula falls flat.

HEADLINE: Money Changes Everything

BYLINE: By ALAN WOLFE. 
Alan Wolfe, the author of ''One Nation, After All,'' is the director of the Boisi Center for Religion and American Public Life at Boston College.

 BODY:
Class Matters
 By Correspondents of
 The New York Times.
 Introduction by Bill Keller.
 Illustrated. 268 pp. Times Books/Henry Holt & Company. 
 Paper, $14.
If Horatio Alger were writing today, his heroine would be a woman named Angela Whitiker. Whitiker first came to the attention of New York Times readers in 1993, when the reporter Isabel Wilkerson wrote about her son Nicholas, then 10, and his struggle to avoid the gangs of urban Chicago. Twelve years later, Wilkerson returned to the Whitiker family as part of the paper's series on class in America, now published in book form as ''Class Matters.'' 
 Nicholas, it turns out, failed to do much with his life. But his mother succeeded beyond almost anyone's dreams, including her own. Thirty-eight, with six kids and an additional stepchild, she left behind the notorious Robert Taylor Homes of her past to earn $83,000 a year as a registered nurse. Her income, impressive as it sounds, leaves little over for luxury, but she is confident that at least some of her children will have a head start in securing a position in the middle class.
 Jeff Martinelli's life went in the other direction. Bypassing college for a well-paying job at Kaiser Aluminum as a 20-year-old, Martinelli stayed with the company for nearly 30 years, until the Spokane, Wash., plant where he worked closed down in 2001. Without a college credential, he did not have much chance of finding comparable work, and ended up exterminating bugs in people's homes at half the $60,000 salary he earned at Kaiser. Although he feels lucky to have a job at all, he knows that his son, Caleb, is unlikely to taste the joys of middle-class status that his father once knew.
 Class (and with it, race) will always be with us; not even the most Candide-like economist could deny that your chances of surviving Hurricane Katrina depended on whether you had sufficient financial resources to own a car. True, some will always move up as others move down, although in recent years Americans, who pride themselves on their upward mobility, have experienced a considerable amount of the downward variety. ''Class Matters'' aims to do what novelists like Dreiser and Fitzgerald and satirists like Veblen once did: to get us thinking about the ways in which money and social status influence who we are. 
 So the stories told here bring the lives of actual people to bear on statistics and social science theorizing. Anthony DePalma recounts the intertwined tale of two immigrants, John Zannikos and Juan Manuel Peralta. They shared more than a first name; both arrived illegally in the United States, spoke little English and were determined to make a better life for themselves than they would have had in Greece or Mexico. But Zannikos came in 1953, at the start of the long postwar boom, while Peralta crossed the border in 1990 in a more difficult economy. Peralta worked in one of Zannikos's diners until his temper got the better of him. ''To him,'' DePalma writes, ''jobs are interchangeable -- just as he is to the jobs. If he cannot find work as a grillman, he will bus tables. Or wash dishes. If not at one diner, then at another.''
 Karl Marx told us that society would split into two classes; today we have as many as there are yogurts. Consider the many flavors of the rich. Only in America -- more properly only on ''nature's ultimate gated community,'' as Geraldine Fabrikant describes Nantucket -- can old-money aristocrats become objects of sympathy. It may not be an American tragedy to witness a tycoon buying up the six-bedroom manse you inherited from your grandparents to make space for his wine cellar, but in such ways do the ultrarich differ from the merely rich. 
 You cannot tell the richer class from the middle class by what its members wear, drive or eat. Godiva chocolates are available to the financially strapped secretary on her way to that naturally ungated community called Staten Island. The cruise ship, yesterday's supreme status symbol, features onboard climbing walls for children whose parents sign up to shop at the discount outlets in the Virgin Islands. The actual class markers are those you rarely see; there are 9,000 personal chefs in America these days, compared with 400 a decade ago. 
 Some class mobility in America is neither up nor down but sideways. Peter T. Kilborn relates the travails of Kathy Link, whom he found in Alpharetta, Ga., about to move her family to Charlotte, N. C. Alpharetta cannot escape the realities of class; its $400,000 homes are too expensive for telephone repairmen and assistant supermarket managers. But it is also classless in a particularly exurban way. Kathy, an ''executive Gypsy,'' sits in the same traffic jams as all the other wanderers from soccer matches to tennis lessons.
 The first substantive article featured in both the original New York Times series and in ''Class Matters'' is the most poignant: Janny Scott's story of three heart attacks. Jean Miele, a well-to-do architect, survived his relatively successfully; ''time is muscle,'' heart surgeons say, and Miele, rushed to a world-class hospital, saved the one and preserved the other. Will Wilson, an office worker for Consolidated Edison, received angioplasty and a stent, but only after originally being taken to a hospital that offered neither. Ewa Rynczak Gora, an immigrant from Poland working as a maid, was the unluckiest of the three; after neglecting her own health, she was not well served by visits to emergency rooms and treatments forgone because medical insurance would not cover them.
 Even before the tax cuts of 2001 and 2003 offered stupendous breaks to the very rich, the United States was already transforming itself into a society in which merit counts -- and in which merit is determined by what your parents earned and where your grandparents came from. Back when Americans still had a sense of shame, we called such morally arbitrary advantages unfair, sometimes even unjust. Now we ignore them in favor of debates about gay marriage or stem cells. ''Class Matters'' seeks to change that and I, for one, hope it does. If its stories of unearned breaks and unwarranted misfortune do not make your blood boil, you probably left your social conscience on the ferry to Nantucket.

HEADLINE: Other Voices: Were Readers Prepared for the Hurricane?

 In that post-cold-war era of relative peace and prosperity, serious newspapers like The Times should have more tenaciously focused on the intractable problems that beset this nation -- growing and festering just below the surface -- like the crumbling infrastructure needs of our great cities.

BARBARA ALLEN KENNEY

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Editorial Observer; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: Building the Great Firewall of China, With Foreign Help

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG

 BODY:
In April 2004, a few weeks before the 15th anniversary of Beijing's massacre of protesters in Tiananmen Square, the top-ranking staff members of The Contemporary Business News in Hunan were called into a meeting. An editor read a message from the Communist Party's propaganda department warning that protests or media coverage of the anniversary would not be tolerated as June 4 approached. Though the message was routine, the reporters were warned not to take notes.
 But Shi Tao, one of the journalists, did. He e-mailed them to a Chinese dissident in America, who posted them on the Web. A few months later, Mr. Shi was arrested. This April, he was given 10 years in prison, a sentence the judge called lenient, for disseminating state secrets abroad. 
How did the police find Mr. Shi? His newly published verdict states that the prosecution relied in part on information given to the government by Mr. Shi's e-mail provider, Yahoo.
 America has a bipartisan human rights policy in China. It is called trade. The idea is that Western companies will bring Western values -- especially when they develop the Internet, supposedly an unstoppable force for openness. But Mr. Shi's fate is the latest piece of evidence that it's not working out that way.
 China now has more than 100 million Internet users, more than any nation but the United States. But as the Internet booms, China is growing more politically closed. Its government has used the Internet masterfully as a steam valve, allowing Chinese to participate in a world that is modern in all senses but one. A controlled Internet may seem like an oxymoron, but China has one. Sophisticated filters block access for users in China to ideas about democracy, human rights, Taiwan, Tiananmen and other sensitive subjects. Type in ''democracy'' on a search engine in China and you get a limited choice of government-approved sites, or nothing at all, or a warning that the word is prohibited. If you use one of these words in an e-mail message, chat room or blog, you will be censored, and possibly arrested.
 American companies like Microsoft and Cisco have all sold China security tools and firewalls that China has turned into political controls. The companies argue that it is not their fault if China misuses standard politically neutral technology. They are right, but many foreign Internet companies in China have gone beyond neutrality. Some, including Yahoo, signed a pledge of ''self-discipline'' in 2002, promising to follow China's censorship laws. Many Internet portals actively censor their Chinese Web sites.
 Snitching on a client to totalitarian police is still another category of bad behavior, a move that should shrivel the keyboard fingers of Yahoo users everywhere. Since Chinese legal verdicts so rarely come to light, it is unclear how commonly this occurs. It has always been easy to imagine China's government asking Internet companies for the e-mail of, say, a foreign businessman competing against a Chinese business or government entity. Now it is easy to imagine Yahoo complying. 
 The company admits it linked the e-mail to Mr. Shi's telephone for the police. Its only comment has been a brief declaration that its local subsidiaries must obey local laws, regulations and customs. But according to the verdict, the Yahoo subsidiary that turned in Mr. Shi is in Hong Kong. It has no more obligation to obey China's security laws than does Yahoo in Sunnyvale, Calif.
 It was the force of capitalist profits, not Communist law, that compelled Yahoo to hand over Shi Tao and its unapologetic response seems devised to ingratiate Yahoo further with Beijing. Last month, Yahoo spent a billion dollars to buy a 40 percent share of Alibaba.com, China's largest e-commerce company. It was the single largest foreign investment in China's Internet sector, and like everything else in China, it would not have happened without the good will of the party. 
 The Chinese market is so delicious that companies will do almost anything to get in and stay there. A few anecdotes among many: Rupert Murdoch banned the BBC from Star TV, his China satellite network, after the BBC ran reports about human rights in China. In the mid-1990's, Chrysler in Beijing refused to rehire a Jeep factory worker who missed work while locked up for holding a Christian ceremony commemorating Tiananmen. Only direct lobbying by Chrysler's chairman got him his job back. 
 In 1999, Fortune magazine held a conference in Shanghai to mark the 50th year of Communist Party rule. The conference was one great big icky fawning session. Gerald Levin, the Time Warner chairman, presented President Jiang Zemin with a bust of Lincoln. Sumner Redstone, chief executive of Viacom, told the meeting that Western media groups ''should avoid being unnecessarily offensive to the Chinese government.'' 
 In many important ways, foreign investment has been good for the Chinese people. It has lifted living standards greatly. China's desire to trade has encouraged new permission for thousands of Chinese to study abroad, which is also a force for liberalization. Foreign businesses have promoted legal reform, although largely in commercial law.
 But let's not pretend that foreign investment will make China a democracy. That argument was born out of desperation and self-interest. Because China is too lucrative a market to resist, American and European businessmen have ended up endorsing the party line through their silence -- or worse. They are not molding China; China is molding them. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); ELECTRONIC MAIL (90%); INTERNET & WWW (90%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (90%); CENSORSHIP (89%); COMPUTER NETWORK SECURITY (84%); ANNIVERSARIES (78%); POLITICS (77%); JOURNALISM (77%); WEB SITES & PORTALS (76%); CHAT ROOMS (75%); BLOGS & MESSAGE BOARDS (75%); ARRESTS (74%); EVIDENCE (73%); TRENDS (73%); FIREWALLS (72%); POLITICAL PARTIES (72%); WRITERS (72%); COMPUTER NETWORKS (71%); JAIL SENTENCING (69%); RIOTS (68%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (68%); HUMAN RIGHTS (67%); ECONOMIC NEWS (59%) News and News Media; Sentences (Criminal); Electronic Mail; Demonstrations and Riots; Foreign Investments; Economic Conditions and Trends; Politics and Government

COMPANY: YAHOO! INC (85%); MICROSOFT CORP (52%)

ORGANIZATION: Yahoo Inc

TICKER: YHOO (NASDAQ) (85%); MSFT (NASDAQ) (52%)

HEADLINE: A Thriving Market, And a Community Pillar

BYLINE: By BRIAN P. MURPHY

DATELINE: CLIFTON 

 BODY:
TO drivers zipping by on the Garden State Parkway, the beige-brown shingled sign for Corrado's Family Affair stands out just as much as it did when James Corrado and his three sons opened their produce market here 30 years ago. From the ground, though, it's clear that Corrado's has become something more. The store remains family owned by ''the triumvirate'' -- the brothers Peter, Joey and Jerry -- and managed by 8 of their 17 children. But the enterprise has expanded into a mini-empire that takes in 23 acres along the Crooks Avenue border that separates Paterson and Clifton.
 The store hardly resembles its humble beginnings, though it sits just blocks from the Paterson farmers market where James Corrado first speculated in fresh fruits and vegetables in the 1950's and opened a retail store a decade later. Corrado's now sits entirely in Clifton, but it is still all Paterson in spirit. James's father, Pietro, started in the produce business at the downtown Island market in the 1920's and 1930's. 
In many ways, Corrado's could be a business-school case study. It does not advertise, yet its 35 checkout registers hum even at 8 a.m. on a Monday; Sundays, the parking lot is a carnival spurred by the lure of fresh produce. The store primarily stocks produce, meats and fish. Corrado's sells little prepared food. This is a store for people who do their own cooking.
 ''We can sell a head of lettuce for 29 cents,'' explained Peter Corrado, 59, one of the ever-present Corrado brothers at the front of the store. ''Nobody can beat that, so why waste money on advertising? When people stop in, they stay to buy more.''
 Although Mr. Corrado years ago gave up personally picking up produce from South Jersey farms, he is at work when two trailers roll in at 6 a.m. daily. September is canning season, and when families begin brewing their own tomato sauces from ripe Jersey reds, the store will move 600 to 800 bushels of tomatoes in a single day, and 30,000 in a season.
 Corrado's still draws many of the same Italian-American customers it originally served, but as Paterson and Clifton and surrounding areas have become more populated with Latino and Middle Eastern immigrants, so has the inventory and staff. A tub of fresh ricotta is bordered by globes of homemade mozzarella, and on a recent Sunday the store offered four types of fresh feta cheese (Romanian, Bulgarian, French and American). Red and green peppers are flanked by serranos, hot bananas and finger hots. Prickly pears imported from Mexico can be found among Sicilian, Italian, and Chinese eggplant.
 The international flavor of the store is not a result of market research. Instead, customers asked, and the store responded, even when they were not sure what they were ordering. 
 ''It started with tahini.'' Mr. Corrado said. ''Twenty years ago, Turkish immigrants came in looking for it. I had no idea what it was, but we got some. Now we have tahini from two countries.'' 
 The instrument that allows this diversification is laughably low-tech: the board.
 Whenever a customer asks for something not on the shelves, it's written ''on the board.'' When Corrado's vendors stop in, they check the board. If they can supply an item, the brothers have no qualms about taking a risk. Tahini, peppers, cilantro, avocados and different varieties of mango -- all unknown to the Paterson-born and Fair Lawn-raised Corrados -- became staples in the store because of the customers' initiative and the owners' listening skills. 
 Corrado's revolves around the needs of its customers. In the 1970's, silk screeners with dye-stained hands would shop in the store after work; today, the mills that made Paterson the Silk City are long gone, but local retailers, Muslim halal butchers in nearby South Paterson and Latino laborers have replaced them. With a Bangladeshi floor supervisor and a multilingual staff, you get the feeling that anybody on the planet could shop in the store.
 This unyielding embrace of change has not been the norm in sometimes nostalgia-mongering Paterson, New Jersey's third-largest city behind Newark and Camden. 
 The Corrado family's public departure from the farmers' market in the 1970's, spurred by rival shareholders who denied James Corrado a renewal on his lease, was less a departure from the city than a retreat from its politics. When Mr. Corrado bulldozed his sprawling old shed, moved up the street to Clifton, and established an enterprise that gilded the demographic and economic changes others were resisting, he rejected a mind-set -- not a locale. 
 As Paterson's 150,000 residents saw factory after factory close and vacant lots spring up to cover 12 percent of the city, Corrado's prospered. If Paterson is to be reborn, Mr. Corrado believes, it will be a grass-roots resurrection that happens one block at a time. 
 Corrado's took a risk by expanding in a place that others had abandoned, embracing change and showing respect to local customers whose arrival others lamented. They offer variety without pretense. Of the feta cheeses, Mr. Corrado gestured toward one of his employees and said:. ''This isn't a fancy store like Zabar's. It's for people who cook. We're not a discount store, and I don't have time to describe each cheese to you on a little card, but if you want to taste it, that man will help you out.''
 Try the cheese. Sniff the 20 feet of olives. If you don't find what you need, ask someone, then come back in two weeks.
 It will go on the board.
