HEADLINE: Whoops! There Goes Another Pension Plan

BYLINE: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
ROBERT S. MILLER is a turnaround artist with a Dickensian twist. He unlocks hidden value in floundering Rust Belt companies by jettisoning their pension plans. His approach, copied by executives at airlines and other troubled companies, can make the people who rely on him very rich. But it may be creating a multibillion-dollar mess for taxpayers later.
 As chief executive of Bethlehem Steel in 2002, Mr. Miller shut down the pension plan, leaving a federal program to meet the company's $3.7 billion in unfunded obligations to retirees. That turned the moribund company into a prime acquisition target. Wilbur L. Ross, a so-called vulture investor, snapped it up, combined it with four other dying steel makers he bought at about the same time, and sold the resulting company for $4.5 billion -- a return of more than 1,000 percent in just three years on the $400 million he paid for all five companies. 
Two years later, as the chief executive of Federal-Mogul, an auto parts maker in Southfield, Mich., Mr. Miller worked on winding up a pension plan for some 37,000 employees in England. The British authorities balked at the idea, fearing that such a move would swamp the pension insurance fund that Britain was creating; it began operations only last April. But the investor Carl C. Icahn has placed a big bet that Federal-Mogul will pay off after the pension plan is gone; he has bought its bonds at less than 20 cents on the dollar and is offering money to help the insurance fund. He, too, stands to make millions. 
 Now Mr. Miller is at Delphi, the auto parts maker that was spun off by General Motors in 1999. If past is prologue, one of the most powerful turnaround tools at his disposal will be his ability to ditch Delphi's pension fund. He did not return numerous telephone calls seeking his views for this article, but in the past he has said that his first priority at Delphi was to ''resolve'' its ''uncompetitive labor cost structure.'' That includes the roughly $5.1 billion gap between the pensions it has promised employees and the amount it has put aside to pay for them. 
 If the obligation to make good on Delphi's pensions eventually lands, in whole or in part, at the door of a governmental guarantor, few should be surprised. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation has become an increasingly popular option for private-capital funds and other investors who are seeking to spin investments in near-bankrupt industrial companies into gold. The key is to shift the responsibility for pensions, which weigh as heavily as bank loans on a company's balance sheet, to the pension corporation.
 The same financial alchemy has been performed at Polaroid and US Airways, at textile companies like Cone Mills and WestPoint Stevens, and at a host of smaller companies over the last four years. And bankruptcy specialists say that it is almost certain to keep happening, because shedding pensions -- and pensioners' health care obligations -- is turning into an irresistible way to make a high-risk investment pay off. 
 ''It's become a kind of system to bail out companies,'' Thomas Conway, vice president of the United Steel Workers of America, said of the pension corporation, which Congress created in 1974 to protect retirees if their employers went bust. ''People have been able to use it tactically, as a business strategy, and I don't think that's what Congress meant.''
 Over the long term, the rate of defaults is clearly rising, said Lynn M. LoPucki, a professor of law at the University of California, Los Angeles, who has tracked the large companies that have shed their pension plans while in bankruptcy since 1980. 
 Less obvious is precisely how the trend will ultimately affect retirees, who sometimes have their pensions cut in the process. The cuts appear to be hitting more and more workers, but the government has not calculated how many since 1998.
 Nor is it certain how the trend will affect taxpayers, who may wind up on the hook if the rising tide of failed pension obligations overwhelms the resources of the pension corporation. A year ago, when the agency last reported its balance sheet, it had $39 billion in assets and $62.3 billion in liabilities, leaving a shortfall of $23 billion. The Congressional Budget Office on Friday estimated that the deficit will widen to $86.7 billion by 2015 and $141.9 billion by 2025.
 Mr. Ross, the investor who picked up the five dying steel companies, said he also thought that the current practice of sending failed pension plans to the federal guarantor ''needs some reforming.'' 
 But, he added, the private sector was not to blame. ''If we're going to continue defined-benefit pension plans at all,'' he said, ''I really think we need to look at who enforces the rules, what the rules should be, and why there isn't a meaningful, risk-based system.''
 In a risk-based pension insurance system, companies that run failure-prone pension funds would pay higher premiums than the companies that manage their pension plans more conservatively. But instead of charging more, the government has been waiving the pension rules, he said. ''When you start giving people waivers,'' he said, ''you're creating a time bomb.''
 Like defaulting on a loan, terminating a pension plan significantly lightens a company's balance sheet: the business instantly becomes more valuable because it does not have to use its cash flow to pay for past mistakes. 
 But defaulting on a loan affects the lender, who presumably vetted the borrower and charged interest commensurate with the risk. Defaulting on a pension, on the other hand, affects the pension corporation, which is required by law to accept a low premium unrelated to the risks it takes.
 James A. Wooten, a pension-law historian who is a professor at the University at Buffalo Law School, said that Congress knew it was creating an imperfect system when it established the pension corporation in 1974, and that it expected to make improvements later. The bill was highly contentious, and Congressional leaders struggled mightily to achieve compromise in the last chaotic months of the Nixon presidency, with the Watergate scandal roaring around them.
 In the beginning, they set pension insurance premiums at a token $1 per employee. Today, the basic premium is up to $19 a head, but Congress has found it hard to raise the rates even remotely enough to cover growing claims. Some companies have warned that if they have to pay more for their pension insurance, they will stop offering pensions.
 ''They took cautious steps, and those cautious steps weren't enough to prevent the abuse of the insurance program,'' Mr. Wooten said. ''Once there's insurance, you have an incentive to run up liabilities to get more out of the insurance.''
 MR. MILLER'S arrival at Delphi in July, and the intense labor negotiations that have followed, are signals that the auto parts industry may be in for a long cycle of bankruptcies and restructurings, like those that reshaped steelmakers and are beginning to transform airlines.
 ''Something has to happen to all of these liabilities and cost structures,'' said Mr. Ross, who has said that he may invest in Delphi, the world's largest auto parts supplier, after those changes are made. ''Delphi needs to sort out these complicated relationships before anybody will buy it. Something has to change.''
 Delphi isn't the only troubled automotive company to catch Mr. Ross's eye. He has also expressed an interest in Collins & Aikman, a manufacturer of automotive interiors that is already in bankruptcy, and he recently invested $30 million in a French auto parts maker, Oxford Automotive. But because of Delphi's size and its relationship with G.M., its former parent, any big cuts in its so-called legacy costs -- mainly pensions and retiree health care -- would send reverberations through the auto industry.
 No one says it will be easy for Mr. Miller to cast off Delphi's pension plan -- it never is -- but he was dealt a good hand when he came to the company. Not only would the federal pension guarantor end up with at least part of Delphi's plan if the company went bankrupt, but the company could also rely on an unusual promise that G.M. made to the United Automobile Workers seven years ago -- in far better times -- that it would take over any part of the Delphi pension plan that the pension agency refused. Generally, the agency caps pension payouts at about $45,000 a year, to workers who are 65 when the plan fails. For younger workers, the limits are a good deal lower. 
 G.M.'s involvement means that Delphi workers -- unlike many unlucky employees of Bethlehem, United Airlines and Polaroid -- might not lose any benefits if their plan were taken over by the government. 
 (G.M. also promised to assume all medical costs for retirees if Delphi faltered, an obligation estimated at $9.6 billion. Securities analysts have been parsing the language of the promise, trying to determine if G.M. must really shoulder this entire amount, and the extent to which Delphi would have to pay G.M. if it rebounded later. G.M. has its own heavy obligations to retirees and can ill afford to take on more.)
 Savvy investors know that the existence of these two guarantees gives Mr. Miller great power -- the right, if he needs it, to make someone else pay Delphi's large and growing debt to its work force. If he plays his hand skillfully, Delphi could end up shedding billions of dollars of debt without depriving unionized employees of any promised benefits.
 To unload the pension fund, however, Delphi would have to declare bankruptcy; a company cannot send an unwanted pension plan to the government without first persuading a bankruptcy judge that it cannot otherwise survive. And if Delphi is to file bankruptcy, it may have to decide quickly. New, stricter bankruptcy laws take effect on Oct. 17, and companies that declare bankruptcy after that date will face a range of restrictions on how much they can pay in executive bonuses and on how long they can take to work on their reorganization plans.
 Mr. Ross said that he was not privy to the negotiations at Delphi but that he thought it likely that Mr. Miller would declare bankruptcy before the law tightened. ''Delphi's a big company,'' Mr. Ross said. ''I think he'd be very concerned about his ability to retain a whole management team there'' if he could not pay bonuses. And controlling the schedule for reorganization is an important tool for debtors negotiating with creditors. ''I would be shocked if he would give up the leverage that that tool gives him,'' Mr. Ross said.
 But other analysts speculated that Mr. Miller might well delay a bankruptcy filing past Oct. 17 because he could win wage concessions from the union if he kept the pension plan going. ''The carrot that he has to offer is, 'If you keep working for an extra year, you get more benefits, and those benefits are more valuable to you because those benefits are guaranteed not by us, but by G.M. and the P.B.G.C.,''' said Jeremy I. Bulow, a economics professor at Stanford. ''That's something Delphi can use as a negotiating tool.''
 While that may be good news for Delphi, its workers and its shareholders, it could be very bad news for G.M., the pension agency -- and perhaps, ultimately, taxpayers. ''The policy problem is that we let companies get this deeply in hock to the federal government,'' Professor Bulow said. ''It's kind of a rolling the dice, a heads-I-win-tails-you-lose kind of thing.''
 COMPARED with Delphi, Bethlehem Steel looked grim when Mr. Miller arrived in September 2001. Like other big integrated steel makers in the United States, Bethlehem had been fighting a losing 20-year battle with foreign competition and low-cost domestic mini-mills. ''I came here to find a way not to file for Chapter 11,'' Mr. Miller said upon his arrival. But by mid-October, Bethlehem was in bankruptcy.
 The company was being killed by its legacy costs -- the accumulated promises to retirees it had been making for decades. Bethlehem had whittled down its work force over the years in an effort to cut costs, but by doing so it simply created more retirees to whom it owed pensions and health benefits. 
 By the time Mr. Miller took over, the company had some 95,000 retirees and just 12,000 active workers to generate enough revenue to pay their benefits -- a hopeless proposition. Retiree health care alone was costing Bethlehem about $125 million a year. In the 1990's, the stock market boom made its pension fund look healthy, but when the boom ended and the pension funds' assets fell, the company had to make up the difference. By November 2002, Bethlehem faced liquidation.
 That is when Mr. Ross stepped in. A big concern then -- as it is now at Delphi, the airlines and elsewhere -- was the pension plan. When the time came to turn it over to the pension agency, officials there realized that Mr. Ross was poised to set off as much as $550 million in extra ''shutdown'' benefits -- available only to workers idled by a plant closing -- by briefly shutting some operations before taking over. The government would have to pay the workers' basic pensions in any case; federal officials thought that if the workers were to get any additional money, it should come from Mr. Ross. (Shutdown benefits are an option that is also available to Delphi.) 
 Steelworkers applauded these arrangements, but the pension corporation seized Bethlehem's pension plan before Mr. Miller had the chance to shut down operations and activate the extra benefits. The union, Mr. Miller and Mr. Ross all complained, but Mr. Ross nonetheless found enough additional money to offer retiring employees $50,000 buyouts and to set up a trust fund to pay for LTV and Bethlehem retirees' health insurance. ''We felt a moral obligation to those workers, even though we had no legal obligation,'' Mr. Ross said.
 In the end, what bothered Mr. Conway, the union leader, was not so much Mr. Ross's inability to wring more money out of the pension system or his remarkable profit on the deal. What troubled him, he said, was that the country seemed unable to take any lessons away from the demise of the steel companies and how it affected so many working people. ''It just staggers us that America's not caught on to what's happening to it,'' he said.
 ''Here's Ford and General Motors, now competing against a lot of U.S.-based transplant companies that have no obligations to any work force,'' Mr. Conway added, referring to the nonunion factories that Toyota, BMW and other foreign-owned car companies have built in the United States. ''That's a tremendous advantage. How does a mature American industry that has obligations to its work force compete with that?''
 Because global competition is driving the trend, Mr. Ross said the country should look for a new way -- maybe a value-added tax on imports -- to bolster the pension-insurance program or to provide health care to retirees. He said he had suggested this approach to some members of Congress, but in vain. ''So far, they've really seemed more interested in lashing out at China,'' he said.
 For now, people approaching retirement are left to hang on and hope.
 ''What happens is, typically, you've got a boat that holds 40 and you need seats for 50 and people are all trying to hold on till the end of their career and get their promise,'' Mr. Conway said. ''We frankly don't know how to do it, if there's no other assistance out there to help you do it. The P.B.G.C. isn't the solution.''

HEADLINE: Big Tax Increases, Small Tax Rebates

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
IN a few weeks, just as New York City becomes embroiled in a typically noisy mayoral campaign, most homeowners across the boroughs will receive a $400 check in the mail, and most likely a soothing note from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, thanking them for their sacrifices on behalf of the city.
The check is a rebate, the second of three annual $400 payments authorized by the State Legislature to line the pockets and calm the feelings of homeowners upset by an 18.5 percent tax increase adopted at Mr. Bloomberg's request during a fiscal downturn a few years ago.
 But if you get that check, expected to be mailed on Oct. 1 to those who qualify, you might want to take a look at your recent tax bills, because that $400 may not buy as much tax relief as it used to: while property tax bills in New York remain far below the legendary tax bills in the suburbs, they have been rising over the last four years. 
 A review of individual property tax records by The New York Times shows that in the last four years, the tax burden for average owners of private homes, co-ops and condominiums has gone up far more than the $400 rebate -- an average of nearly $1,100 a year (before rebate) across the city.
 And while that is a paltry increase by suburban standards, where the bigger the rise the greater the bragging rights, many taxpayers see it as the beginning of a significant shift in the role of the property tax in New York City. Property taxes have deliberately been kept low over the years to encourage home ownership, with the local income tax making up much of the difference.
 ''It used to be that our real estate taxes could be described as ludicrously low; that is certainly not the case anymore,'' said Patricia Dolan, the president of the Kew Gardens Hills Civic Association, who lives in the small two story-detached house she grew up in on 73rd Terrace. ''We have people who are hurting.''
 In the last four years, tax bills of single-family homes have risen 62 percent, according to the analysis by The Times, including a 4.3 percent tax rate increase set to be adopted by the City Council in the next few months and applied retroactively to July, to comply with complex provisions of the state laws governing city property taxes.
 At the same time, tax bills of individual co-op and condo apartments that were higher, on average, to begin with, have gone up about 43 percent, including a 1.5 percent tax rate increase set to be adopted this fall, to comply with the property tax laws, City Council officials said. Taxes went up an average of $1,680 for condos and $943 for co-ops.
 Driving the tax bills are increasing property values, improved and some say more aggressive assessment practices, and a longstanding policy by the City Council to use extra revenue produced by assessment increases as extra revenue for the city, rather than reducing tax rates. And yet these increases are only the beginning. 
 Though higher market values, in the greatest real estate boom in memory, have been recorded recently by tax assessors, some of the resulting increased assessments have not been added to tax bills. By law, they are being phased into the tax base over many years -- over five years for co-ops and condos and rental apartment buildings; no more than 20 percent over five years for one-, two- and three-family homes; and 30 percent over five years for four- to 10-family buildings.
 As a result, market values already recorded on the books of the Department of Finance, based on last year's sale prices, will eventually generate hundreds of millions of dollars in extra tax payments, in slow but steady increases for years to come: $1,300 a year, on average, for single-family houses at the latest tax rates, $1,100 a year for condos, and $615 for co-ops. (Of course, if the boom goes bust, and property values drop, much of this future tax burden could go away, too.)
 And with prices moving steadily upward, more such increases are likely. In the first half of this year, for instance, average co-op and condo prices in Manhattan rose 33 percent, according to Miller Samuel, a real estate appraisal company based in Manhattan.
 Ms. Dolan's parents bought her house in Kew Gardens, Queens, when it was new in about 1940 for $6,300, with a $5 down payment from winnings in the Irish Sweepstakes (they couldn't afford the extra $350 for a garage behind the house, she said). 
 In the last four years, assessors raised the market value on her house from $277,000 to $500,400, and her annual tax bill went up 50 percent, from $2,028 to $3,040, and will probably continue to $4,355, when the current market value is phased in. Values are still rising in her part of Queens, she said, raising the fears that high taxes will destabilize the finances of elderly people on fixed incomes. 
 She described a neighbor in her 90's, a retired hairdresser who is concerned about her tax bills. ''She has to pay her taxes from whatever savings she has and her Social Security.'' 
 The story of rising taxes is similar in the most affluent neighborhoods in Manhattan, but the order of magnitude is considerably higher, especially for mansions and town houses, and the newest flashiest market-rate condominiums.
 Taxes on Mayor Bloomberg's own 18-foot-wide Upper East Side town house rose from nearly $45,000 four years ago, to about $71,100 this year (less the $400 rebate the records show he is entitled to), an increase of 59 percent. The tax bill will eventually go up to nearly $86,000 based on the latest tax rate and the current market value, $9.1 million, up from $6.4 million four years ago.
 Owners of single-family Manhattan town houses who always thought their taxes were an outrageous bargain, when compared with the suburbs, can no longer say that. Manhattan town houses average nearly $21,800 a year in taxes this year, up $7,600 from four years ago, according to the Times study, and will probably rise to more than $32,300, when future scheduled increases are phased in. 
 Yet these Manhattan homeowners are still getting a significant discount compared with their suburban cousins, because their houses, valued by the Finance Department at an average of more than $3.3 million, are worth more than the average suburban house, and their true tax rate is lower. 
 Another measure of the increase in property taxes is the number of residential properties with tax bills of more than $50,000 a year. Four years ago, 196 properties were listed, compared with 547 this year, with the list topped by new condominiums at the Time Warner Center.
 The highest taxed private house on the list is the 40-foot-wide town house on East 63rd Street of Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire financier. His taxes are now $192,000 a year, up from about $125,000 four years ago. 
 Older condominiums and co-ops are protected by laws designed to dampen tax increases. For instance, they are assessed as if they were older rental buildings, based on rental income rather than their ever-rising sale prices. Then individual owners get a special abatement of between 17.5 and 25 percent off the taxes due.
 So, in Manhattan, average taxes on condos were up about $2,000 to about $7,140, while co-ops were up about $1,500 to $4,900, per apartment. 
 But newer, luxury condos are assessed considerably higher, as if they were market-rate luxury rental buildings. And among the highest taxed is Donald J. Trump's three-story 6,000-square-foot condo atop Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue. This year's tax bill would have totaled about $188,000 for Mr. Trump. But like most other individual condo and co-op owners, Mr. Trump's apartment qualified for a 17.5 percent condo abatement, saving $32,900 in taxes. (His condo also qualified for a $400 rebate.) Four years ago his tax bill was $111,000, after a $23,600 abatement.
 ''The taxes in this city are ridiculous,'' Mr. Trump said. As for the mayor's $400 rebate, he said: ''That is just wonderful. Today that buys one tank of gas.''
 Last year, Mr. Bloomberg was not shy about publicizing the rebate, posing at a center for the elderly in Queens with a giant cardboard cutout of a rebate check, with his name featured most prominently in the upper left hand corner. 
 This year, the checks are scheduled to go out in the middle of an election. 
 Asked about the timing, Sam Miller, an assistant commissioner at the Department of Finance, said they would be issued the same time of year they were last year, when the timing was dictated by the date the state enabling legislation was passed in Albany. 
 Yet, the rebate program was set up to make it seem as enticing as possible to taxpayers. Most homeowners pay their taxes through their regular monthly mortgage payments to their banks, which in turn pay the city. But the rebates are mailed back directly to the homeowner.
 Similarly, owners of co-op apartments pay their regular taxes to their co-op as part of their monthly maintenance. But the rebate checks are mailed back directly to the individual owners who qualify for them, last year, along with a note from Mr. Bloomberg. (Some co-op boards, however, impose offsetting assessments at the same time to lessen the pain of the assessment.)
 Owners of one- to three-family homes and co-ops and condos who use their homes as their primary residences are eligible for the rebate, but only if they owe less than $25 in back taxes for earlier years. Taxpayers already enrolled in tax exemption programs that have residency requirements are automatically eligible for the rebate. If you received a rebate last year and haven't moved, you will also qualify for this year's rebate, according to city officials.
 Tenants who pay property taxes through their rent checks are not eligible, nor are brownstone owners who live in buildings legally defined as four-family houses, nor are investor owners of rental buildings.
 The rebate was originally set to roughly equal the cost to the average homeowner of the 18.5 percent increase, but as tax burdens have since risen, so has cynicism by individual taxpayers and other public officials, who would rather see a permanent reduction in tax rates than a rebate handed out at the discretion of the government. 
 ''Getting your dollars back is nice,'' said Robert Spalter, who lives with his wife, Laura, in a two-story house in Riverdale, in the Bronx. ''But I don't have any expectation that they will really roll back tax rates ever again.''
 Dee Vandenburg, a state employee, pays only a few hundred dollars a year in taxes on her small Staten Island house, a former summer cottage. But Ms. Vandenburg, who is president of the Staten Island Taxpayers Association, said that ''at some point it is a big thing with working families and a big thing with the seniors on a fixed income.'' 
 Michael Slattery, a senior vice president for research at the Real Estate Board of New York, an industry group, said that at a time when rising property values were being driven by extraordinarily low interest rates, it might make more sense for the city to lower rates as market values go up. 
 But are taxes rising because values are rising or because assessors are more assertive and uncompromising? City Councilman David I. Weprin of Hollis, Queens, chairman of the Finance Committee, said that ''there is no question that assessors have been very aggressive.''
 ''It is troubling,'' he said. He tells of constituents who have seen their official market values rise by 30 percent, three years in a row. He said he is always running into worried constituents who say ''if the property is worth what they say it is, I will sell it to them.''
 In response, Finance Commissioner Martha E. Stark said that her staff was ''doing what it is supposed to do, which is to accurately value properties.'' She took office just as a corruption scandal in the assessors office was laid bare, and put an end to lax assessment practices, in which, city officials said, assessors set informal guidelines, limiting the change in market values from year to year.
 Instead the city used improved computer models to estimate new values for every one- to three-family home in the city each year. 
 Many good-government groups and analysts say the rebate is bad public policy, adding one more layer of complexity and protecting one more special-interest group -- homeowners.
 Many public officials privately agree, but find it difficult to turn down such a popular program. ''You don't hear the Democrats making an issue of property taxes,'' said Edmund J. McMahon Jr., director of the Empire Center for New York State Policy.
 But some economists and policy analysts say that, if anything, property taxes on homeowners are too low in the city, especially viewed against the backdrop of significant rises in market values. 
 Several years ago, the city's Independent Budget Office issued a study concluding that despite its low property taxes, homeowners had a tax burden that was above average in the state because of the city income tax and sales taxes. 
 ''When you factor in all the taxes, homeowners have never gotten the break they think they got,'' Mr. McMahon said. 
 Gregory J. Heym, the chief economist for Halstead Property, a brokerage firm, who previously worked for the Real Estate Board, said he viewed the rebate as ''just a thing to appease voters.'' He said that since property taxes have been kept artificially low for homeowners over many years, many homeowners are convinced they are still getting a bargain, even as their taxes are starting to rise. 
 ''The sad thing for the homeowner is that property taxes should be even higher, so how can they complain,'' he said. ''It is a system that needs to be completely overhauled but probably never will be.''
 Details on the Study
 THE New York Times study of property tax bills reviewed assessment and tax abatement records for all 996,000 tax lots in New York and computed and compared estimated tax bills for the city fiscal years ending in June 2002 and June 2006. 
 The estimates include property tax rate changes under consideration by the New York City Council that would raise tax rates for residential properties and lower them for office buildings and utilities. The increases, retroactive to July 1, would be reflected in bills sent out in January.
 The maps and summary data include only properties with valid tax bills in both years. It excludes properties for which 90 percent or more of the tax burden was eliminated because of abatements or exemptions. The tabulations, therefore, may differ somewhat from figures published by the Department of Finance. In addition, abatement data for 2006 were estimated from the previous year's data. JOSH BARBANEL

 Correction: October 2, 2005, Sunday
 An article on Sept. 18 about taxes in New York City described the pattern of rising property taxes imprecisely. The average annual tax bill in 2005 was nearly $1,100 higher than the average bill in 2001. The tax bill did not increase nearly $1,100 each year.
 By the time tax bills reflect higher market values and increased assessments, which will be phased in over many years, projected bills for single family houses will average $1,300 more than the total this year, not $1,300 more per year going forward; condos will end up paying $1,100 more, and co-ops $615 more.

HEADLINE: Post-Katrina, Bricks and Mortals

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
WHEN President Bush went to the virtual ghost town of New Orleans on Thursday to champion a plan for its recovery, his words -- ''This great city will rise again'' -- carried familiar echoes. The American way of facing these calamities: get up off the ground, dust (or dry) yourself off and start over. Dream big, and take back what nature took.
 After Hurricane Andrew thrashed Florida in 1992, for instance, a high-powered civic group, We Will Rebuild, sprang up, with a vow to make a ''better, healthier community.'' Surveying San Francisco after the earthquake and fire of 1906, the magazine Sunset proclaimed that the city would end up ''greater and more beautiful.''
Nearly a century later, Mr. Bush used similar language and imagery. ''The people of this land have come back from fire, flood and storm to build anew, and to build better than what we had before,'' he declared. 
 Yet shadowing Mr. Bush's plans for a new New Orleans is an uncomfortable notion. Hurricane Katrina was a brutal natural disaster, but it also touched off a manmade one. The chaos and mismanagement, the violence and the racial tensions broadcast to the world recalled not earlier natural disasters, but something else: the strife in Los Angeles after the Rodney King verdict in 1992; the race riots in Detroit and Newark in 1967, from which neither city fully recovered.
 In his speech from the French Quarter, Mr. Bush promised ''one of the largest reconstruction efforts the world has ever seen,'' and the federal government will undoubtedly inject tens of billions of dollars into New Orleans.
 But whatever the financial and engineering challenges in reviving New Orleans, the harder truth is that cities often have difficulty bouncing back from manmade misfortune that throws into doubt their potential as safe places to live and work and invest, urban affairs experts say.
 Even before Katrina, New Orleans was sliding in prosperity and in population, with high rates of crime and poverty. The question now is whether the jarring aftermath of the storm has fatally wounded New Orleans's reputation in the eyes of the public -- residents and business owners who left and those who might consider moving to New Orleans in the coming years.
 Hurricane Andrew was nearly as devastating to areas of South Florida, and people also fled, some permanently. But many returned, and while some areas were economically scarred for years, they are now booming. The '92 hurricane did not stir the kind of social strife that tends to make cities seem unwelcoming, perhaps because the underlying fabric of those communities was not frayed in the first place.
 On the other hand, the lesson of Detroit and Newark is that these events can push teetering cities over the edge. Like New Orleans, they were struggling with a wilting industrial base and the flight of the white middle class. The riots hastened those trends, in part because there was a loss of faith that the cities were governable.
 The resurrection of New Orleans, in other words, may hinge on whether the storm is remembered more for the collapse of the levees, which can be repaired and bolstered, or the collapse of civil order, whose taint is much harder to wipe away.
 ''New Orleans has to rebuild not just its buildings and its political culture, but its image,'' said Joel Kotkin, author of ''The City: A Global History.''
 ''People want to know whether a place is a credible first-world city,'' Mr. Kotkin said. ''What they found in New Orleans was that underneath the gloss and facade of a first-world tourist attraction was a third-world reality. It will take a lot of work to erase that view.''
 Max A. Herman, an assistant professor at Rutgers University in Newark who studies urban unrest in the 20th century, said he had been struck by the similarity between the media images after Katrina and those during the violence in Detroit and Newark. The 1967 riots flared after accusations of police brutality in each city.
 He cautioned that the situations were dissimilar in many respects, saying that the looting in New Orleans seemed to have been relatively insignificant and received more attention than it deserved. He suggested that there was more sympathy nationally for New Orleans and support for its recovery than was the case with Detroit and Newark in the late 1960's. Back then, black residents were often viewed, unfairly or not, as having brought the disaster upon themselves by attacking the police and burning buildings.
 But Mr. Herman pointed out that while big employers will probably return to New Orleans, lured by vast sums in federal aid, the small businesses that are the backbone of neighborhoods may be more hesitant. 
 ''It's about not trusting the local government anymore to protect their interests,'' Mr. Herman said. ''That really came up in Newark and Detroit as well. There is really going to be frustration and disappointment among those small-business owners in New Orleans, who are going to say, 'Why wasn't more done to protect us?' And without them, you really can't have a community.''
 Still, is this too pessimistic? Before Katrina, people in New Orleans tended to be more rooted to the city than the populations of many other major cities. That may indicate their loyalty to New Orleans, and their willingness to return and make it thrive.
 In fact, a Gallup poll of urban attitudes across the nation conducted over the summer found that 53 percent of New Orleans residents were extremely satisfied with their personal lives in the city, the highest percentage for any of the 22 cities in the poll, according to Richard Florida, a professor of public policy at George Mason University, who worked on the poll.
 ''From the images that we saw on TV and from what the experts have been saying, one might think that New Orleans people hated their city, that they thought that it was a dump, that they were horribly dissatisfied,'' Mr. Florida said. 
 ''New Orleans has this incredible potential that the pundits are missing, in that the regular people of New Orleans love their city and get a life satisfaction out of it more than people in Denver or New York or Boston,'' he said.
 One challenge, then, would seem to be to harness this affection to energize and guide the recovery. But residents have been flung across the region. Who knows how many will return, and when. It will not be clear for months how embittered they have become from the evacuation and relief effort.
 It is widely held that for urban redevelopment to succeed, people must be actively involved at the neighborhood level. Can they trust in a reconstruction campaign mounted by the same officials who were supposed to have helped them in the days before and after Katrina? After all, New Orleans has a history of political corruption, so the people may already have had a jaded view of officialdom before the storm.
 The president, of course, journeyed to New Orleans on Thursday to make it clear that government would not let the city down. His speech harked back to the clarion calls made after other natural disasters -- from the flood that decimated Galveston, Tex., in 1900 to the one that hit Grand Forks, N.D., in 1997 -- but at one point, its tone changed.
 The poverty exposed by Katrina, Mr. Bush said, ''has roots in a history of racial discrimination, which cut off generations from the opportunity of America; we have a duty to confront this poverty with bold action.''
 Whether intentionally or not, Mr. Bush was echoing a declaration made almost 40 years ago.
 ''It is time to adopt strategies for action that will produce quick and visible progress,'' it went.
 Those words come from the report of the Kerner Commission, which investigated the riots in the 1960's that roiled Detroit, Newark and much of urban America.

HEADLINE: Codey Leaving A Mixed Bag As His Legacy

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE 

 BODY:
SO Richard J. Codey gets a phone call one recent evening. 
 It's Senator Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for governor, looking for some political advice from his more experienced colleague about an intraparty fight he had gotten involved in over a state Senate seat in Bergen County.
''He said, 'What do you think?''' Mr. Codey recalled, smirking faintly at the memory. ''I said, 'Jon, that's your business. I can assure you that I'm not getting involved.''' 
 With fewer than four months left in his term as acting governor, Mr. Codey finally seems comfortable enough to revel in some of the benefits of being a lame duck before returning full time to the job he never had to give up, that of Senate president. 
 His story about Mr. Corzine was in part intended to illustrate that he can now pick his battles, accomplishing what he can during his remaining time as the state's chief executive while leaving some of the more contentious tasks to whoever replaces him in January.
 Indeed, after Gov. James E. McGreevey resigned in disgrace in August 2004 and lingered in office for about three more months, Mr. Codey stepped in to provide a steadying influence in Trenton. But when he steps down in January, he will be leaving behind many of the nagging problems that existed when he came in: long-term budget imbalances, a perilously bloated pension system, a near-empty Transportation Trust Fund, oppressively high property tax rates and despite his best efforts, uncertainty over the future of the Meadowlands sports complex. 
 ''Codey's personality and demeanor ended up being a perfect match for what the state needed in an acting governor,'' said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University, ''which was someone who give the impression that he was capable of governance. That's no small thing, and people appreciate it. But having said that, it may be a bit sobering to New Jerseyans that we will face enormous problems next year.'' 
 For his part, Mr. Codey seems mostly satisfied with what he will have accomplished in his 14 months in office.
 ''In many ways I'll miss it, because the thing about being governor is whatever the issue of the day is you can have a direct impact,'' he said during a wide-ranging interview last week in his district office here. ''But as for the headaches that come with being governor -- the problems -- if something happens after that, hey that's Corzine's problem, not mine.'' That does not mean he is entirely happy to be handing over the reins, whether it is to Mr. Corzine or to the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Doug Forrester. There are numerous indications that Mr. Codey, who identifies himself when making telephone calls as ''the Gov,'' is not quite ready to stop performing on a statewide stage.
 There are small indications, like the prototypes for an order of thousands of bobble-head dolls scattered around his office preserving in plastic for all eternity a grinning, red-haired governor. 
 And there are bigger clues, like the fact that Mr. Codey remains resentful of the way he was muscled out of contention for a full term as governor by Mr. Corzine and his allies. Mr. Codey also caused a stir recently by briefly toying with the idea of jumping into a contest for Mr. Corzine's Senate seat, which Mr. Corzine will have to vacate if elected governor.
 ''The only thing I can say,'' Mr. Codey finally said, ''is that I wish I had a few more months.''
 Whatever concerns he may have about unfinished business, however, Mr. Codey is already being credited by colleagues and voters alike on one important score.
 ''I think that, first and foremost, Governor Codey's legacy will be that he restored the integrity of the high office he holds,'' said Senate Minority Leader Leonard Lance, a Republican and a friend who held the Bible for Mr. Codey as he took the oath of office.
 Polls certainly seem to indicate that Mr. Codey has exceeded expectations in that regard. A recent Star-Ledger/Eagleton survey showed Mr. Codey, a caretaker governor and non-candidate, beating Mr. Forrester in a hypothetical race by the same margin as the hard-campaigning, free-spending Mr. Corzine. 
 ''It's flattering,'' said the usually blunt Mr. Codey, clearly trying to restrain himself about the political implications of things that might have been.
 Of course, those numbers are only a snapshot.

No Miracles, but Steady Progress
 When he came into office last November, the state faced an economic crisis brought on by years of ruinous borrowing, putting in jeopardy such basic obligations as pensions for state employees and money to keep public trains and buses running, and resulting in property tax rates that had ballooned to become the highest in the nation, with no relief in sight.
 Mr. Codey, who had warned when he assumed office that he was ''not some great reformer,'' had no miracles up his sleeve. 
 Instead, the veteran legislator -- a product of the Essex County Democratic organization -- had to settle, in many cases, for incremental progress. 
 In an effort to close the budget gap, he frankly declared in his State of the State address that he would be canceling property tax rebate checks for more than a million homeowners, only to compromise at budget time with Assembly Democrats by maintaining them, but at reduced rates.
 He appointed an inspector general to investigate governmental waste and fraud, but did not go as far as creating an independently elected attorney general, as some advocates of reform have proposed.
 He signed into law a measure -- first proposed by Mr. McGreevey in an 11th-hour pang of conscience -- to ban political contributions from state contractors, a practice known as ''pay to play,'' but did not address the still-unregulated ability of county bosses to move campaign funds around the state, a practice known to insiders as wheeling.

Limited Boat Rocking
 Part of the reason for his limited accomplishment in these areas, many veterans of state government say, is that Mr. Codey was always a temporary governor and, once he withdrew from the governor's race, a lame duck.
 ''He would have been in a position to do a better job if he had been a candidate for governor,'' said one lobbyist and public affairs consultant, Alan Marcus. ''Instead, he acted in many ways like a Senate president instead of a governor and didn't rock the boat. What changes were brought about in terms of the pension system? What changes were brought about in terms of the number of political hacks on the state payroll? Is the transportation trust fund in place? I just don't think Codey was in a position as acting governor to do those things.''
 Similarly, Mr. Lance said that he was ''disappointed'' at Mr. Codey's performance in some of those major areas -- particularly on pay-to-play reform and on the budget, which prompted the Republican leader to file suit against the Codey administration this summer for relying on borrowed money -- and that his status as an acting governor was not by itself an excuse for lack of accomplishment. 
 ''The acting governor has all of the powers of an elected governor,'' Mr. Lance noted. Still, Mr. Lance said, ''He only will have had one year and arguably after a great trauma, restoring integrity goes well beyond appearance to fundamental substance.''
 Likewise, Mr. Marcus said that the most important aspect of Mr. Codey's legacy will be that he brought back ''grace and public confidence'' to the office.
 Mr. Codey himself was notably reflective on the topic of his inability to institute more reforms over the past year. 
 ''Looking back, I don't know if I could have done, maybe scrapped state government as we knew it, or tried to reinvent it,'' he said. ''You know, maybe another governor can. But that would not be easy because you're dealing with entrenched institutions that have their own constituencies.''
 As Mr. Rebovich said, ''His substantive accomplishments may not be enormous, when you think about what he inherited, he gets a fair amount of credit personally.''
 So as the end of his unexpected turn in the governor's office approaches, the question for Mr. Codey is what to do with his newfound political capital.
 For one thing, he said, he intends to get more actively involved in the governor's race. Mr. Codey explained that although he talks to Mr. Corzine ''about once a week,'' tensions between the erstwhile rivals kept his role to a minimum until now. 
 ''I think things just took their course, and the tension that was there when I was deciding whether or not to run and obviously run against him has dissipated,'' Mr. Codey said.
 After his most recent conversation with the senator, Mr. Codey said, he expects things do get much busier. ''I say, 'Jon, all the local candidates ask me to come and campaign for them,''' he explained. 

Eager to Campaign
 He said that Mr. Corzine responded by saying that he wanted to start scheduling more events with Mr. Codey immediately.
 But if that settles Mr. Codey's short-term political agenda, there remains the question of how he plans to govern for the next four months. Mr. Codey said that he wants to solidify some of his legislative goals, like improving the state's mental health care system, providing additional millions of dollars to state parks and founding a ''steroids task force'' to look into the abuse of performance-enhancing drugs among student athletes.
 He also claimed credit for changing, if not eradicating, tolerance in the state for corruption among public officials. ''I think if you're a politician in New Jersey, you've got to be a moron'' to try something illegal, he said.
 Mr. Codey also hinted that he has several other ambitious initiatives in mind before he leaves, although he said it was premature to talk about them. ''We're going to have a few surprises for you,'' he said. 
 For instance, as recently as Wednesday his office announced a proposal to adopt California's stricter emissions standards for vehicles sold in New Jersey by 2009.
 Whether he can achieve anything substantive is another matter. As it is, even some of Mr. Codey's relatively modest initiatives now look uncertain. 
 His efforts to reach an agreement with the Giants for a new football stadium in the Meadowlands is looking increasingly tentative, with the team balking at the state's demands to share the facility with a huge shopping and entertainment complex.
 Mr. Codey suggested that some of the state's most serious problems are too politically perilous for anyone to address at the moment. 
 On the idea of replenishing the Transportation Trust Fund through a gas tax, for instance, Mr. Codey said: ''How do you do it when that's the No.1 complaint of the people in New Jersey today and in our country? With the high price of gasoline, sometimes I don't fill my car anymore, because you know I'm on a fixed income. I'm giving them $20 instead of the $45 I need. I mean, it's tough.''
 Mr. Codey suggested some of the state's other challenges may be insurmountable for the foreseeable future. 
 ''State government is so vast,'' he said. ''It takes myriads to change the way we run it, if in fact it's changed at all. And I would probably say the odds are against big change, no question about it.''
 For now, it is unclear what role Mr. Codey envisions for himself. There has been much speculation about what he might do next -- including talk of some appointment by Mr. Corzine, if he is elected governor, to head one of the state's powerful authorities -- but the governor said he has yet to decide.
 ''You know, I always say in politics you never should plan to take a particular position in a particular year, because it may not be the right time,'' he said. ''I don't know if in fact I want to run for another job, and if I do what would be the right one at the right time, so I just take one day at a time and try to be the best state senator I can possibly be and I want to help the new governor.''
 Mr. Codey did say that he was sure of one thing, at least, which was that he was no longer interested in Mr. Corzine's Senate seat because the demands of bouncing between New Jersey and Washington ''is not conducive to good family living.''
 And if it came down to it, he said, he would have absolutely no problem going from being governor of a large state back to Senate president and legislator from West Orange. ''When people ask, 'How could you be Senate president after you've been governor?' That's for people with a big ego, and I don't think I have one.'''
 ''There's no regrets, none at all,'' said the governor, repeating what has become a familiar refrain. ''You know, when I started in politics, I never thought I'd have the opportunity to be governor for 14 months. For the most part its been rewarding. At times its not easy. But I don't regret my decision at all.''
